Quezon (2025) Watched Quezon in cinemas last week. It aims for epic, but somewhere between the dramatic speeches and historical gravitas, it loses its spark. Ambitious, yes, but the heavy-handed theatrics and slow pacing make it more exhausting than engaging. A decent attempt at history, but not one Iâ€™ll remember fondly.

Pinaka maganda sa trilogy ng bayaniverse, Very Good casting lahat walang tapon, hopefully maraming Pinoy Ang makapanood neto, sana maaga mailabas sa Netflix para mas maraming audience, the Philippines need this kind of film, Jerold Tarog is now my favorite Filipino film Director.

A few weeks ago Cinemartys reminded all of us the massacre committed by Leonard Wood in Mindanao. But somehow, this movie humanized Leonard Wood. Making him charismatic and only wants to serve the people, at worst, a bureaucrat. But Leonard Wood was racist and an imperialist. His writings about the Philippines, depicting Filipinos as mostly backward and savages, were the reason why the US government did not give us independence immediately. And yet the movie not only gave credence to his racist tirades, it made it into facts. This is wrong in so many levels. I understand that we should unmask our heroes, but making the founding fathers as villains is a slippery and dangerous slope for a nation that easily forgets its own history. At a time that our sovereignity is in peril by outside and even inside forces, a movie questioning our genesis is a bit irresponsible. Not to mention the hypocrisy of a rousing speech against patronage politics then thanking the sister of the sitting president and the daughter of the dictator in the end credits. Admittedly, Quezon is a much better film than Goyo, but it's irrelevant at this point. [Glorietta]

i had a chance to watch their block screening on the first day and got to see their amazing actors, mon confiado, benjamin alves, jake macapagal, ana abad santos, and therese malvar, thanks to national university.the concept of making a prequel about the people we call our national heroes is a smart and refreshing move in philippine cinema. the director shows them as normal people with strong political desires, which mirrors the never ending power game we still see today. from emilio aguinaldo to manuel quezon, all the way to the marcos-duterte tandem, i must say they follow the same pattern. we treat these men like mythical figures and grow up with a clean version of them. then the film shows them bargaining, manipulating, and protecting their own interests, and you realize the cycle never stopped. it feels heavy at first because you hope someone in that era stood as the clear hero, but the more the story unfolds, the more you see how power shaped all of them.what i love about this film is that i went inside the cinema thinking I would learn another honest story from our former presidents and understand why they are considered important figures in history, not just because they led the country but because of what they sacrificed during their time. but after watching it, i realized that both emilio aguinaldo and manuel quezon, despite the rivalry and the clear protagonist antagonist framing, never truly cared about the filipino people and were both playing dirty.quezon is a great communicator and strategist. these helped him rise from being a lawyer to becoming the second president of the philippines. we grow up hearing his name and thinking of one of the best presidents we ever had. in the film, all he talks about is independence, but I never actually saw the real reason behind it. was he doing it for the country, for the people, or to validate his own hard work and protect his power and money.it took me almost two months to write this review because the film stayed in my mind longer than i expected. every time I tried to sit down, i ended up thinking about another scene or another line that hinted at something deeper. itâ€™s not the kind of film you watch and forget the next day. it leaves you with questions that donâ€™t settle right away.i kept replaying how the characters moved and how their decisions shaped everything. the more i revisited it in my head, the more i understood why it bothered me in a good way. it challenges the way we grew up seeing these men. it makes you look past the titles and medals and ask who they were when the doors were closed.

Iâ€™m a Filipino student and we were given a activity, a small film critique for my social studies class worth 20 points for the seatwork and quiz. Ironic enough, this was announced 6 days after I watched the film.When you hear the name Manuel Quezon, what comes to mind is that he was the 2nd most beloved President of the Philippines. A man who fought cases against the poor before as a lawyer, and was able to serve our country, But after watching the film I realized there was a lot more about him. I realized that Quezon wasnâ€™t really much of a good President for his achievements. He is not really effective as a leader or able to accomplish anything for the country. But instead taking the governmentâ€™s power by maneuvering to get what he wants and to establish what once was a blissful tree to a rotten egg. He was a master of playing dirty tricks to bribe the people creating conflict against his rivals causing them to get in the way of propaganda like Osmena, General Wood, and Aguinaldo. Involving the press questioning their political views on both perspectives. Another thing I noticed is that the Americans were actually trying to help the Filipinos as General Wood realized the people didnâ€™t have proper education just from not knowing what independence means. They were helping us to establish better roads and build a proper government system for our country.The biopic not only showcases Quezonâ€™s rise and downfall but alongside how our government is still the same until now. â€œI would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos, rather than a country run like heaven by the Americans, because no matter how bad the Filipino government might be, it can still be improved!â€ To quote Manuel L. Quezon himself, sums up how our government will always run like hell unlike the Americans even though they were also cruel back then. Our independence may never be claimed, but our pride and soul can not be taken for granted. The Filipino government we have today is still running like hell from our corruption, political dynasties, and both parties fighting left and right while the poor are fighting by themselves. No matter how many people vote for a good president, we will always end up in last place as poverty devours us whole. After watching Quezonâ€™s biopic, I realized how important education is for us and our love for everything we have in this country. What I can use from what I learned in this film as a citizen is by being civilly determined and persevering when it is already my duty to vote for the leaders of this country. That I should be a responsible voter in the future by knowing who to vote for and understanding what this stands for. Other factors that I realized to consider are self-dignity and moral values are important to look for in a leader. Patriotism can be as simple as exercising your right to vote and to vote wisely. In conclusion, despite Manuel Quezonâ€™s search for independence and freedom for the Philippines he was unsuccessful. I say that because up to this day, our political system is naive and independence is something we have been fighting for up till this day. Independence not only from other countries colonizing us, but independence from corruption, political agendas, poverty, miseducation and political dynasties.I LOVE THE FILM SO MUCH. Iâ€™m a very big history nerd especially Philippine History so 100% recommended to any historian fan out there. Jericho Rosales and Jerold Tarog (big fan to both of them) did another phenomenal project for not only themselves but to every Filipino. Congratulations! At Maraming Salamat for making this film come true!

jericho rosales alam lang kita kasi kamukha mo aso ng kaibigan ko (this is a neutral statement, cute naman yung aso) i was so pleasantly surprised by how well you acted, consider me a fanâ€¦ i had doubts with the casting at first because irl quezon was a whitewashed mestizo, the stuff of envy for self hating transracial losers on discord, but your acting really sold me, wowâ€¦ 10/10 trapo moves, no wonder nagalit grandbaby ni quezon HAHAâ€¦on a more serious note, i like how this film seems to be tarrogâ€™s way of interrogating himself as a creative, especially with the unintended effect heneral luna (2015) had on swaying the public in support of strongman personas (re: duterte in 2016)â€¦ in what ways is the filipino artist complicit in propaganda? or i guess more broadly speaking, in what ways can art and narratives be co-opted? i like that this movie invites skepticism kumbagaâ€¦ may bisa nga ang kwento oo pero bisa para kanino? bisa para saan / hanggang saan? and i think thatâ€™s why i have a soft spot for itâ€¦ i respect movies that encourage the audience to ask questions. timely siya, in fairness, idk kung intended ba o hindi pero ayun, relevant nga, lalo na in this second marcos presidency where historical distortion thrives precisely because the will to question narratives is being stamped outâ€¦pero speaking of narratives, i wish the power of the masses was portrayed with more depth ğŸ˜­ lalo na dahil next movie tungkol kay magsaysay, grandfather of filipino populismâ€¦ i was disappointed by the scene where woods asked farmers and peasants if they were in favor of independence because it was such a shallow (and quite homogenous??) portrayal of filipino sentiments on US colonizationâ€¦ where are the sakdals?? where is pkp-1930?? itâ€™s historically inaccurate to suggest that all filipinos were passive about independence!!! ğŸ˜­ and speaking of pkpâ€¦ SIGHHH i really donâ€™t have high hopes for the magsaysay movieâ€¦ basic details pa nga lang sa pkp di inaayos, huks pa kayaâ€¦ fact check: the movieâ€™s english subs are wrong, pkp cannot be translated as cpp, those are two different groupsâ€¦ second fact check: nabong was definitely affiliated with pkp but the aglipay-nabong duo did not run under the party name pkpâ€¦ they were republicansâ€¦ important distinction because since when tf was pkp ever allowed on the same playing field as quezonâ€™s nacionalistas?? ğŸ˜­also since weâ€™re already ranting tarrog do NOOOOOTTT try to sympathy bait me with aguinaldoâ€™s flop campaign parade i will never extend sympathy for him i know for a fact that that loser was a collaborator for jpn during ww2 HE HAS NO LOYALTY FOR THE FILIPINO PEOPLE YOU CANâ€™T FOOL ME ğŸ˜­ğŸ¤š

After ğ˜ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¢ğ˜­ ğ˜“ğ˜¶ğ˜¯ğ˜¢ and ğ˜ğ˜°ğ˜ºğ˜°: ğ˜ˆğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜‰ğ˜¢ğ˜µğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜ğ˜¦ğ˜¯ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¢ğ˜­, TBA Studios and director Jerrold Tarog closes the BayaniVerse trilogy with 'ğ—¤ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ˜‡ğ—¼ğ—»' â€” a film that trades the sound of gunfire for the noise of politics, but still burns with the same intensity.Itâ€™s not a war of soldiers this time, but a war of ideals, egos, and ambitions â€” fought in meetings, elections, and through the public eye.Jericho Rosales gives a career-defining performance as Manuel L. Quezon. You can tell he studied Quezonâ€™s mannerisms down to the smallest gesture â€” the posture, the pauses, even the rhythm of his voice. His portrayal balances elegance with cunning charm, showing us both the gentleman, the strategist, the patriot, and the politician.The filmâ€™s structure is bold and stylish â€” divided into four chapters, each framed like a â€œVâ€ (versus) battle, pitting Quezon against different political and historical figures of his time, accompanied by a subtitle based on dialogues in each chapter. It feels very Snyder Cut in its presentation â€” grand, deliberate, and unapologetically significant. The fourth chapter, the longest one, brings everything to a dramatic and climactic close that feels inevitable and tragic.Mon Confiado returns as Emilio Aguinaldo, and once again, he commands attention. His portrayal of a president haunted by legacy and resentment is one of his best performances yet. His dialogues, essentially saying that he did everything he could for the Filipinos, echo with pride and regret.Itâ€™s still surreal to see Game of Thrones veteran Iain Glen as Governor-General Leonard Wood, but even in his few minutes onscreen, he leaves a strong impression with his performance. Romnick Sarmenta also deserves praise for his controlled and weighty take on Sergio OsmeÃ±a, grounding every scene heâ€™s in.The film cleverly incorporates black-and-white silent film sequences, serving as historical vignettes and mirrors of Quezonâ€™s inner world. They show us the contrast between the public image and private intentions. Even more playful are Benjamin Alves and Aaron Villaflor playing not only as the younger versions of Quezon and Joven Hernando in flashbacks but also as actors in those silent films.Karylle shines as Aurora Quezon, bringing class, grace, and quiet strength to her role as a partner who understands the weight of her husbandâ€™s ambition. Meanwhile, Joross Gamboa may be new to the BayaniVerse, stepping into the role of the recast Eduardo Rusca. But he still feels right at home in this trilogy, proving his versatility in dramatic territory.'ğ—¤ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ˜‡ğ—¼ğ—»' is, without a doubt, the most political film in the trilogy. While its predecessors dealt with wars and heroism through action and tragedy, this movie unfolds during the Commonwealth election era, where battles are fought through speeches, alliances, and betrayals. Tarog turns politics into theater, and every act has consequences.If I were to rank all three BayaniVerse films:ğŸ¥‡Heneral LunağŸ¥ˆQuezonğŸ¥‰Goyo: Ang Batang HeneralAnd yeah, this movie may have lacked action compared to its predecessors, and some might find the pacing slow or the dialogue too heavy-structured, but thatâ€™s where its strength also lies. The movie challenges us to listen, read between the lines, and confront the truth that leadership often lives in the grey area between heroism and hypocrisy.What makes this linger isnâ€™t a rousing battle cry, but a haunting reflection: ğ˜©ğ˜¢ğ˜·ğ˜¦ ğ˜¸ğ˜¦ ğ˜³ğ˜¦ğ˜¢ğ˜­ğ˜­ğ˜º ğ˜¤ğ˜©ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¨ğ˜¦ğ˜¥ ğ˜¢ğ˜´ ğ˜¢ ğ˜¯ğ˜¢ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜°ğ˜¯, ğ˜°ğ˜³ ğ˜¢ğ˜³ğ˜¦ ğ˜¸ğ˜¦ ğ˜´ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜­ğ˜­ ğ˜±ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜§ğ˜°ğ˜³ğ˜®ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜¨ ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ ğ˜´ğ˜¢ğ˜®ğ˜¦ ğ˜±ğ˜°ğ˜­ğ˜ªğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜¤ğ˜¢ğ˜­ ğ˜µğ˜©ğ˜¦ğ˜¢ğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜³ â€” ğ˜«ğ˜¶ğ˜´ğ˜µ ğ˜¸ğ˜ªğ˜µğ˜© ğ˜¯ğ˜¦ğ˜¸ğ˜¦ğ˜³ ğ˜§ğ˜¢ğ˜¤ğ˜¦ğ˜´?Still, 'ğ—¤ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ˜‡ğ—¼ğ—»' stands tall as a worthy conclusion to the BayaniVerse, both grand in scope, rich in detail, and haunting in its honesty about power and nationhood. And yes, stay for the end-credit scene â€” whether it truly closes the saga or hints at something beyond, itâ€™s the vague ending that leaves you proud, curious, and reflective all at once.In the end, Tarog doesnâ€™t just tell us who Manuel L. Quezon was â€” he shows us the kind of leader widely regarded as one of the most significant figures in Philippine history.With that being said, Iâ€™m going to give this movieâ€¦8/10! â­ï¸ (Woooo!)

Hell week is over, so I can finally write my recent movie reviews. Let's start with the movie I watched in the cinema this November: Quezon (2025)At first, I had no idea kung paano ang takbo ng kwento, but I've heard and we tackled it with one of our lesson sa ArtApp where we talked about the Art and Society, Art and Politics. Since then, I was curious about how the movie portrayed Quezon, and how his administration affected the Philippines. I'm glad to have a chance to see it in the theater, it was a different experience. This will be long as I did my research a while ago after watching it kasi as someone who is not that literate with the politics, it can be confusing. Pero, it gave me an opportunity to look at the history myself. Quezon Vs. OsmeÃ±aDuring his time, hindi lang Americans ang kalaban ni Quezon. May mga kapwa Pilipino siya na may ibang idea para sa bansa. Hindi na kalaban from outside, but someone beside him. Quezon and OsmeÃ±a were both brilliant, but their visions didnâ€™t always match. Their rivalry wasnâ€™t about hatred. It was about direction. Who can lead the nation better? Which path will bring Filipinos closer to independence? Historically, after passing the Jones Law, Quezon became Senate President, pero kasama niya noon si Sergio OsmeÃ±a bilang Speaker of the House. May ideology clash sa pagitan nila. OsmeÃ±a was more open to gradual transition, maybe compromises. Pero si Quezon gusto ng mas klarong direksyon sa independence. Dumating yung time na naglatag ng Hareâ€“Hawesâ€“Cutting Act, batas na may planong bigyan ang Pilipinas ng independence pero may mga kondisyon tulad nung retention ng US military bases. Si OsmeÃ±a sumuporta, pero si Quezon tumutol, gusto niya tunay na kalayaan. Pinamunuan niya yung campaign para i-reject ang HHC at gumawa ng mas maayos na plano. This eventually led to the Tydingsâ€“McDuffie Act of 1934, which set up a 10-year transition period toward independence. Nagkaayos sila para sa 1935 election: Quezon bilang President, OsmeÃ±a Vice-President. Nanalo sila at nagsimula ang Commonwealth.It is a fact na nag-advance ang pilipinas during his term pero some elites benefited more than the common people, so the effects werenâ€™t evenly felt. Basically, Quezonâ€™s leadership advanced the country on paper and at the top levels, pero hindi lahat nakaramdam ng pagbabago sa araw-araw nilang buhay.Quezon Vs. WoodThere's this Woodâ€™s mission sa Pilipinas, na tinawag na Woodâ€“Forbes Mission, sent by the U.S. para i-assess kung ready na ba ang bansa for independence. Sila ni Forbes literally inikot ang halos lahat ng provinces, tiningnan yung governance, economy, education, at social conditions. Ang conclusion nila? Marami pang Pilipino hindi pa ready mag-govern on their own.At sa totoo lang, hindi sila totally mali. Marami sa mga pilipino noon lalo na ang mga pilipinong walang access sa edukasyon na hindi talaga alam kung ano ang ibig sabihin ng kalayaan. May scene doon sa movie inikot ni Wood yung mga baryo at tinanong ang mga tao tungkol sa freedom, may isang farmer na sumagot, â€œMasarap,â€ kasi akala niya ang kalayaan ay pagkain lang. It is sad but it's true na ang mga tao ay madalas na focus sa araw-araw nilang buhay, lalo na kung paano makakapag-hain ng pagkain sa kanilang hapag-kainan (wow, lalim). Kaya natural na naging skeptical si Wood sa kakayahan ng mga Pilipino na mag-govern.Kahit sa mga elite, may problema rin. Maraming local leaders yung mas interesado sa sariling kapangyarihan at personal gain na kaysa sa long-term good ng bansa. Madali silang magpadala sa opportunism, kaya minsan hindi sila sumusuporta sa reforms. Dahil don, kahit nakapagtayo si Quezon ng institutions at frameworks, hindi pantay yung epekto sa ordinaryong tao katulad ng mga magsasaka, mas nakinabang ang mga elite, habang karamihan ng masa stuck sa poverty, limitadong edukasyon, at lupa.Quezon Vs. AguinaldoThis part builds the tension gradually. I LOVEEE ITTT! The soundtrack, the camera work, everything! Makikita doon sa 1935 presidential campaign ni Aguinaldo. Kasama niya yung supposed VP niya, pero compared sa massive support ni Quezon, maliit lang yung entourage. Low-budget, few supporters, at sa maliit na pagtitipon lang, Di katulad kay Quezon, nasa sasakyan, maraming supporters, parang festival. Sa isang scene, pinapaalis siya sa lugar (hindi ko matandaan kung saan), tapos sinabi niya na hindi na siya babalik. Eto parang dramatization nalang, pero historical fact na natalo talaga siya ng malaki kasi Quezon got around 68% ng vote, habang Aguinaldo less than 20%. It's a matter of nationalism vs. new governance ni quezon."Wala kayong utang na loob."Controversial si Aguinaldo dahil sa mga paratang na involved siya sa deaths ni AndrÃ©s Bonifacio at Antonio Luna. After Tejeros Convention noong 1897, na-execute si Bonifacio at yung kapatid niya. Maraming sources ang nagsasabi na in-approve ni Aguinaldo yung order, sabi niya â€œfor the sake of the country.â€ Later, si Luna naman na-lure sa meeting sa Cabanatuan at pinatay; may mga historians na tinutukoy yung telegram ni Aguinaldo bilang evidence na posibleng siya ang nag-orchestrate. Hindi lahat malinaw, pero malinaw na messy ang Filipino politics noon, halo-halo ang power, loyalty, at personal ambition.Aguinaldo could have humiliated Quezon by bringing up personal matters, pero hindi niya ginawa. Quezon won, became first president of the Commonwealth, and set up the all-Filipino cabinet. He tried reforms like the Rice Share Tenancy Act of 1933, pero marami ang nagsasabi na hindi daw ito effective kasi controlled pa rin ng landlords ang local politics, kaya maraming peasants ang naiwan sa kahirapan.Quezon Vs. JovenFictional siya, I know. Pero, joven served as the eyes ng audience. Sa simula, nung nakita niya si Quezon sa boat, hopeful pa siya, baka this person is really the way to change. Simple pa yung pananaw niya noon, hero si Quezon, clear ang moral compass, he's a good person.Pero habang lumalalim yung kwento, habang mas nalalaman niya yung political struggles, nagbabago rin yung tingin niya. Nakikita niya yung tension kay OsmeÃ±a, kay Aguinaldo, pati sa mga pilipino. Kapag titignan mo, mas naiintindihan mo yung history, hindi na pure heroes and villains ang nakikita mo. People have their own agendas, limits, at minsan kailangan gumawa ng â€œdirty workâ€ para maabot yung goals nila.Nakikita rin natin kung paano yung utang na loob, loyalty, at personal connections gumagawa ng ripple effects sa buong political system, at paano siya nakakaapekto sa mga ordinaryong pilipino.Overall, through technical, I love the cinematography, yung color theory na ginamit nila, yung soundtrack and everything. I love movies like this, and I'm looking forward for the next Bayaniverse ni Tarog, which I think is Magsaysay? Yay, the best president of the Philippines.

Throughout the "Bayaniverse" trilogy we see through the eyes of the fictitious journalist Joven Hernando as he witnesses the rise and fall of the national hero, and of himself. We share his naivete in "Heneral Luna", his awakening in "Goyo", and finally his hypocrisy in "Quezon".The character of Joven stands in as the Filipino people, whose principles waver at the sight of precious opportunity and promise. Joven has never fully let go of his tendency to idolize the man behind the power, his attachment to such figures taught him less to be wary of following their footsteps and taught him more of their machinations and how he could benefit from it all, only to be ultimately discarded after falling victim to the schemes of the "hero" he betrayed his principles for.Like Joven, we are complicit in the ills of our country by our own inaction and tolerance. It is much worse of a sin that we choose to close our eyes even if we have already seen the truth. We have the resources, the history, and the privilege of correcting our mistakes but why do we remain stubborn? We realize our own hypocrisy only when inconvenience has caught up to us.

i watched this a long time ago but iâ€™m only reviewing it now because i have been trying to gather my very conflicting thoughts on itâ€¦ alas, i still have not finished doing that but this review is long overdue.i think itâ€™s an enjoyable movie but there were some times where the filmâ€”iâ€™m not sure whether intentionally ur unintentionallyâ€”romanticizes certain figures that shouldnâ€™t be romanticized at all, and in turn the audience for this film did exactly that. ironically, at the same time this film also tried to paint the figures in a bad light, and thatâ€™s exactly where the lines start to blur to the point you donâ€™t know what the movie is trying to say anymore.i know this comes off as â€œthat one friend whoâ€™s too wokeâ€, but this is the best i can articulate my icky feelings toward this movie right now. in general, i do not think it had a good impactâ€”it had a good concept, but ultimately i do not think it delivered a point at all.this review shares my sentiments quite well.

I get why the Quezon family might not love this.But honestly, thatâ€™s exactly what Gerald Tarog has been building toward since Heneral Luna and Goyo. The trilogy isnâ€™t just about flawed heroes; itâ€™s about a nation that has never been fully ready. Heroes rise because the people, the institutions, the country arenâ€™t prepared to carry themselves. And Quezon leans into that idea.The film asks: What does independence even mean when youâ€™re young as a nation and surrounded by bigger geopolitical forces? Here, politics is spectacle. Everyone is performing, maneuvering, managing appearances. Itâ€™s less â€œbe angryâ€ like Luna, and less â€œblind obedienceâ€ like Goyo. It simply shows you that everyoneâ€”from local elites to foreign powersâ€”is taking us for a ride. And Quezon, in this telling, becomes a product of that pressure. Not a saint, not a villainâ€”just someone doing what the moment required.What fascinated me was how consistent Aguinaldo is across all three films. You didnâ€™t like him before, but here you can finally sympathize. The cast is strong, and the historical texture is rich.My issues are mostly structural. Since this is a biographical piece, the core tension is softerâ€”alam mo na where it ends, alam mo na he becomes a hero, alam mo na we get independence. So the pacing wonâ€™t land for everyone. Luna worked because it tapped into a collective anger at a very specific time. Here, the emotional punch is more muted, more contemplative. I get why Tarog didnâ€™t turn this into an activist film per se, but that choice also holds the film back from being as explosive as the first.Still, as a trilogy capstone, itâ€™s thoughtful and well-acted. I admire the ambition, even if this one didnâ€™t hit me as hard as the earlier entries.

While Heneral Luna showed the good and the bad of public service, Quezon showed the good and the bad of politics. It prioritized storytelling than historical accuracy, and there are a few times that that bias didn't work, specifically with their portrayal of Aguinaldo. It prioritized dialog over cinematography, and weirdly enough is as witty as Heneral Luna but without the stunning establishing shots. While it is not a 100% historically accurate movie, I highly recommend this film to those who think Manuel Luis Quezon is just the "Father of the Filipino Language", as its overall portrayal of him is a flawed politician that had the independence as his goal, but wants to save the Philippines on his own selfish terms.

I consider myself a history nerd and i love movies (obv), so getting to watch this masterpiece alone was a two-birds-in-one-stone situation.Disclaimer: this particular part of history isn't my specialty/fixation, this review is based on the movie direction. As for historical accuracy, would probably need to read up on it again.Firstly, my fav thing about this one was camera work. Props to Pong Ignacio for the brilliant shots (apparently he also worked for the director's other Bayaniverse films which is interestinggg). Secondly, the cinematography (still Ignacio) mmmm chef's kiss. Noticed this especially in wide shots and during the parallel campaign scenes between Aguinaldo and Quezon, where the color grading for Quezon's POV was bright and colorful while Aguinaldo's POV turned into this vintage dull tone that contrasted both of their character progressions/regressions.As a fan of arthouse films, where the direction of the storyline isn't really straightforward, absolutely loved the experimental storytelling which switches back and forth between Joven, Rusca, and Nadia watching the "films" as a narration guide then back to the actual events that happen. Found that very compelling. A scene I found rly funny (probs one of my favorites) was when Quezon and Joven bantered about Plato, Aristotle, Kant, Philosophy, and Ethics plsss (bc I get it help).Another fav abt the film was the score, especially in particular the one when Aguinaldo stood and walked towards the stage to give his speech during the 1935 elections scene, should've had a longer exposure hhhhTo summarize, I love how this depiction on one of the most notable "National Heroes" of the country serves as a critique to the twisted side of the road to the nation's independence and political power plays at the time that led up to world war ii. While there were a few things that irked me (won't spoil), loved Tarog's vision on this.(Also, Iain Glen aka Jorah Mormont in GOT and Batman in DC's Titans was here. Ofc I had to watch)

ğŸ’¬ Jerrold Tarog directs with operatic ambition, closing the Bayaniverse trilogy on a thunderous high noteğŸ’¬ production design flexes hardâ€”every frame is a museum piece, every set a masterclass in period opulence. Pong Ignacioâ€™s cinematography paints history with prestigeâ€”wide shots, warm tones, and war-room drama that feels ShakespeareanğŸ’¬ Jericho Rosales commands the screen as Quezonâ€”flawed, fiery, and magnetic, with a performance that lingers. Supporting cast elevates every sceneâ€”no weak links, just ensemble excellenceğŸ’¬ the film blurs reality and dramatization with reckless confidenceâ€”some scenes feel more myth than memoryğŸ’¬ pacing wobbles in act two, indulging in grandeur over gritâ€”some sequences feel like prestige fillerğŸ’¬ the final act leans hard into legacy-building, sacrificing ambiguity for cinematic sainthoodfavorite scene: the debate was fireâ€”but Quezonâ€™s first wife showing up? That was the plot twist that slappedleast-liked: the transitions between Benjamin Alves and Jericho Rosales as Quezon were jarringâ€”like flipping channels mid-monologueverdict: watch Quezon (2025) for its grand visuals, powerhouse performances, and that debate scene twist that turns history into high drama

such an eye-opener, lalo na if napanood mo na rin yung heneral luna at goyo. it really feels like the last piece of a trilogy about how our so-called â€œgreat menâ€ built the nation â€” and how their flaws shaped it, too. dito, makikita mo si manuel l. quezon not just as a hero, but as a cunning politician who knows how to play the game. rosales nailed it â€” ang galing niya magpakita ng contrast between quezonâ€™s charm in public and his fear and weakness in private.whatâ€™s interesting is how the movie doesnâ€™t glorify him. instead, it shows how trapo politics actually started â€” and how quezon himself helped create that system. the film reminds us na kahit gaano katalino o karisma ang isang leader, tao pa rin sila â€” capable of manipulation and lies. medyo talky lang minsan, but maybe thatâ€™s needed para mas maintindihan ng audience.overall, quezon is a powerful, sobering end to tarogâ€™s trilogy â€” not about heroes, but about the sad, messy birth of our republic.+++SUPER PINOY POGI TALAGA JERICHO ROSALES SO TREW KA MS YANI

Quezon is ambitious, centered on the dramatic rise and political maneuverings of Manuel L. Quezon, bringing into focus both his leadership and the moral complexities that come with power. Directed by Jerrold Tarog and starring Jericho Rosales, the film shows serious craftâ€”period details, strong performances, and a desire to tell a sweeping national story. That said, while the intent is noble and the scale impressive, the film sometimes feels unevenâ€”its pacing can feel heavy with exposition, and certain character arcs or motivations donâ€™t always land with the emotional clarity you'd hope for. Itâ€™s a solid historical drama, but it doesnâ€™t always transcend its genre in all moments.

The humor of the entire film perfectly depicts Quezon's puppet government. The government of 1920s is just the same with the current one. Philippines is a circus and we never learn from it as we continue to masturbate for the elites. ğŸ¡

At its core, I found that the movie reflected my frustration in both the spectacle of political power plays, and the intellectual, moral decay of those who now hold the reins of government. Contemporary politiciansâ€”our so-called traposâ€”-have devolved into near-cartoonish figures: one-dimensional villains who plunder public funds, inherit their influence, and contribute little to the nation beyond perpetuating their dynastic entitlement. In comparison to Quezon, whose brilliance was matched by his ambition and corruption in equal measure, todayâ€™s leaders lack both vision and complexity. For all his duplicity, Quezon established systems that tangibly benefitted the poor in some ways, and he did grant us some period of independence (though thatâ€™s still debated). One cannot form a fixed opinion of him, for his legacy is both admirable and reprehensible. In this regard, Quezon (2025) mirrors its subject: difficult to pin down, simultaneously compelling and shallow. The film dramatizes power and corruption effectively, and inevitably tugs at the viewerâ€™s frustration given the state of current politics. Yet it often flattens the historical depth of Quezonâ€™s time, reducing the struggle for independence and the weight of colonial subjugation into a tale of political maneuvering. The controversy surrounding Quezonâ€™s grandsonâ€™s reaction at the filmâ€™s premiere only reinforces the persistence of the Great Man myth, the impulse to sanctify flawed figures rather than confront their contradictions. While the Bayaniverse in general deconstructs this narrative, I think Quezon (2025) only partially succeeds. What emerges instead is a reflection of both the man and the nation: brilliant in flashes, compromised in execution, and perpetually caught between reverence and disillusionment.

First, QuezMena is real. This movie feels like both an ending and a beginning. For me, Quezon isnâ€™t â€œbayani enoughâ€ to close this trilogy; heâ€™s more like the start of what could be a pangulo-verse.Quezon is a master player in politics. The appointment game scene is one of my favorites because it shows how Quezon skillfully maneuvers people and the government itself. His ambition, driven by greed and power, is disturbing, yet Jericho Rosales portrayed it so convincingly that I couldnâ€™t look away! ampogi. Quezon is selfish and trapo, and thatâ€™s what makes him believable. He mirrors the very kind of politics we see today, shifting how leadership and power are perceived in our system.I also liked how Joven became aware of what was really happening. He refused to be swayed again and stood firm in what he believed in. The two-hour film gave justice to how this trilogy ends. My favorite part is when Quezon said that being a hero is all about perception. That line sums up the whole point of the movie: that history and heroism depend on how we choose to see them and we create heroes in our likeness.

10/10 = MASTERPIECE I didnâ€™t expect this film to affect me the way it did. I thought I was ready, that it would simply be another historical piece about a man Iâ€™ve always admired. Instead, it left me still and uncertain, as if it reached into what I believed and rearranged it. It has been a long time since a film made me feel this kind of quiet turmoil.I have always seen Quezon as one of the strongest figures in our history. I saw him as a leader who carried both intellect and heart, a man who stood for what the Filipino could be. Watching this version of him felt painful. The film showed a Quezon who was cold, distant, even cruel at times. I disagreed with it deeply. Yet I could not turn away. It felt honest in its discomfort, as if the film was reminding me that greatness is never pure and that power often leaves scars no one else can see.I kept trying to defend him in my mind, to separate the man from the portrayal, but I realized that was the experience the film wanted me to have. It wanted me to struggle with the idea of Quezon himself. It wanted me to feel both admiration and doubt. That inner tension became the most human thing about the entire experience.When the credits rolled, I just sat there. I couldnâ€™t move. I couldnâ€™t even think clearly. It reminded me how rare it is for a film to make me pause, to make me reflect not just on history but on the kind of leaders and ideals I believe in. It left me unsettled, but it also left me grateful.I still believe in Manuel Luis Quezon. I still see him as one of our greatest. Yet this film made me look at him again with clearer eyes. It made me realize that true admiration accepts flaws, questions myths, and still chooses to understand. That realization is what stays with me.Quezon (2025) gave me confusion, pain, and awe all at once. It made me think harder about pride, power, and the weight of building a nation. It is not an easy film to love, but it is a necessary one. And for me, that makes it a masterpiece.All the discomfort, all the challenge, all the awe I felt comes together in one simple truth. The film made me feel something that reminded me why I love history, leadership, politics, and philosophy.

Quezon at OsmeÃ±a RETRO BLpinayflix finds: "20 pesos at 50 pesos nauwi sa alam niyo na" "Ah, banal-banalan kang burat ka !" isa sa linya ni Quezon sa pelikula, pero sa totoong buhay, ito ang sigaw ng lahat sa mga uhaw sa kapangyarihan pero bulag sa bayan. Pag nanonood ka, akala mo nakikinig ka lang sa mga balita ngayon. Parang bawat eksena sa Quezon, bawat debate, bawat campaign parade â€” ay hindi na bago sa atin, dahil nangyayari ito sa totoong buhay. Ang mga salita, galaw, at taktika ng mga nasa kapangyarihan ay paulit-ulit, predictably corrupt, at puro palabas lang.Ika nga nila, "Ang magulong bayan ay salamin ng magulong politika." Hanggang ngayon, hindi naglalaho at patuloy pa rin na umiikot sa ating realidad. Sa palabas na ito, ipinakita kung gaano kadumi ang politika: nakakasuka, nakakagalit, nakakatakot. Pero alam naman nating lahat, itâ€™s just the tip of the iceberg. Mas nakakatakot pa, dahil hanggang ngayon, wala pa ring tunay na pagbabago, at wala pa ring nakukulong. Ang ganda rin ng portrayal ng mga journalist â€” ipinakita kung paano sila naging mataâ€™t tainga ng bayan. Nakakalungkot lang isipin na may ilan sa panahon ngayon na nagpapadala sa impluwensya, nagpapabayad, o nagpapagamit. Pero naniniwala akong mas marami pa ring tulad ni Joven â€” mga taong marunong magbago ng paniniwala para sa mas mabuti, marunong mamulat, at may tapang tumindig sa katotohanan. Bukod sa journalists, binigyan din ng pansin ang mga filmmakers. Ang pelikula ni Nadia ay simbolo kung paano naaapektuhan ang opinyon ng publiko sa bisa ng mahusay na kwento. Madaling maimpluwensiyahan ng propaganda, political ads, o social media narratives.Sa trilogy, masasabi kong ito ang paborito ko. May halong sarcasm pero masaya ang paraan ng pagkukwento. Isa sa pinakanagustuhan ko ang campaign scene â€” maliwanag at parang pista, pero sa kabila, naroon ang lungkot at muted na kulay, na parang isang funeral.Sa huli, napanood natin ang sinasabi ni Quezon na "hindi natin mapanonood" â€” parang ang tingin niya, habang buhay ay matatago ang baho ng pabango. Marami sa mga politiko ngayon ay ganoon din: puno ng palabas, sakim sa kapangyarihan, at bulag sa pangangailangan ng bayan. Para sa akin, hakbang na ito para mas mamulat at lumawak ang pananaw ng mga Pilipino. Nakakatuwa dahil hindi lang siya pangalan sa history books; nabigyan siya ng boses, ng puso, at ng karakter. Ang pelikulang ito ay magsisilbi bilang paalala ng paulit-ulit na dumi at kasinungalingan. Pero sa huli, nananatili ang katotohanan sa mata ng mga nakasubaybay at mulat.
the crash outs r funny ngl ToT

the good:- i like na hindi nila binigyan masyado ng nuance si quezon dito. all throughout heâ€™s just this cunning and ruthless asshole who happens to be the president and a senate president before that. weâ€™ve seen countless pieces of media na pinapakita mabubuti niyang ginawa at niroromanticize buhay niya so it was very refreshing to see jerichoâ€™s version of quezon na masama ugali all throughout yet he never came across as shallow and one note. no art is meant to be isolated in vacuum so by placing it with another like the quezon movie prior to this gives you a fuller picture of who quezon is, even when theyre not entirely accurate.- was taken aback by how playful and satirical the movieâ€™s tone was considering that itâ€™s supposed to conclude the bayaniverse trilogy. galing. fave ko yung silent movie scenes grabe kuhang kuha yung blocking acting score at makeup! also works really well as a narrative device and cleverly points out how ridiculous quezon can be. - gusto ko yung movement ng camera it really made the movie entertaining- fave line: hindi ako kulangot wag mo kong binibilog!the bad and the ugly: - why remove the sakdalistas? gets na this is a movie about larger than life historical figures but the sakdalistas were popular enough to win a seat in the congress so bakit wala sila sa movie? the whole movie is structured around who quezon is going up against at different points in his political career so it wouldâ€™ve been the perfect opportunity to explore the perspective of the masses and could have made the ending/message stronger but ok whatever. including the sakdalistas in the story couldâ€™ve shown a different side of quezonâ€”one that was insecure enough to actually sabotage figures who are way less powerful than him even when he was already the commonwealth president- why portray filipinos as ignorant/unlearned when it comes to independence? that was the only time na may representation ang ordinaryong pilipino na nagsisilbi ring stand in for the audience tapos in that scene they chose to depict filipinos as mangmang na hindi alam kung ano pinaglalaban nila e kung tutuusin sila na nga yung nakarealize early on that independence should be achieved immediately hindi katulad ng filipino elite noon na kumapit pa rin sa colonial forces and chose delayed independence because they didnt wanna lose their privileges yet - not enough hate for the other key players. not enough hate for aguinaldo (but its okay bc we have luna movie and goyo movie to compensate for the lack of aguinaldo hate) but what bothers me the most is that thereâ€™s not enough hate for wood. leonard wood is depicted as this diplomatic and level headed guy who just wants to do his job so he can go home even though historical accounts say otherwise because heâ€™s anti filipino, and orchestrated the massacre in bud dajo, etc. at the end of the day, mananakop siya na ang tingin sa mga pilipino ay mangmang na kailangan ng colonial intervention. ang mga amerikano din naman ang naginstitutionalize ng padrino system and the filipino elite just took advantage of it so why are they making it seem that quezon was the one who established such system? the issue isnâ€™t about the movie omitting or adding events for creative purposes (it's a movie after all), the problem lies with the larger picture it ends up painting by taking those liberties and to me it just reeks american propaganda and i dont think the movie is aware of that. i know this is about quezon, i know this is a satire, pero kailangan ba si quezon lang yung ivivillainize/satirize? pagvillainize kay quezon gusto pagvillainize sa mga kano ayaw? eme- ewan andami ko ring issues pa like di convincing for me yung relationship ni joven at quezon and yung eventual split nila, yung over sa exposition na dialogue tipong subtext nawawala kasi lahat laid out na for you through dialogue, etc.

An eye-opener to Filipinos that a politician will remain a politician no matter the effort done to save a country. Unfortunately, the Philippines has long flourished from the gamble of our historical figures; you cannot win if there is no price to pay, and this factual portrayal of Quezon is a testament to that.Galing ni Jericho Rosales at nagaya niya â€˜yung ugali ni Quezon. Havenâ€™t watched Quezonâ€™s Game so I canâ€™t make comparisons just yet, but ultimately, hindi ko nakita si Jericho throughout the filmâ€”kitang-kita, instead, si Quezon, as well as OsmeÃ±a and Aguinaldo.

Ang panonood ng "Quezon" ay parehong pakiramdam ng pakikinig sa isang kakilalang naglalarawan sa isang taong nakadaumpalad mo na, ngunit hindi pa lubos na nakikilala. Kaya matapos makinig sa mga kuwento, may responsibilidad na kilalanin pa nang husto ang taong iyon sa kung anumang layuning mahalaga para sa iyo.Ang panganib lang dito ay kung paano tatanggapin ng nakinig: maniniwala agad-agad o aalamin muna ang kabuuang konteksto.Sa Araling Panlipunan/Sibika, limitado ang pagpapakilala kay Quezon. Kaya kung gagamitin itong pangunahing materyal ng DepEd at literal na bibigyang-interpretasyon, mayroong tendensiyang matuon sa "sensationalism" ang talakayan.Ngunit gayundin, magandang ipinakita ang kabuuang karakterisasyon ni Quezon at kung paano siya naging biktima rin ng sistema ng politika sa panahon ng pananakop ng mga Amerikano. Gayunpaman, sa personal kong opinyon, nakulangan ako sa pagpapakita kung paano tinawid ni Quezon ang grey areas--sa pelikula, tumatawid lamang si Quezon sa itim o sa puti. Kung maipakikita sana ang bigat ng pagkaipit sa sistema at pagpili na lamang sa "lesser evil", mas naging balanse at nagkaroon ng dagdag na layers ang kaniyang tauhan.Nakakabahala rin ang idea na mula pa noon ay umiiral na ang parehong maruruming taktika sa politika. Na parang ang pelikula ay direktang salamin ng kasalukuyang lagay ng politika sa bansa.Super like: Pagganap ni Jericho at ang acting ensemble. Karakter ni Nadia. (Napaisip tuloy ako if may 2nd version itong pelikula, charot!!!)

SOOOO good. the gossip-speak and exaggerated press language is exactly the form of storytelling i love, and personally how i think philippine history should be told. this is exactly how i envision noli me tangere to be translated into film. i also liked that the direction of the film is theatrical, to show the nature of politics as a performance ("room where it happens" type of)!also: they're obviously in love

Honestly before watching the film I got a bit skeptical, not because of the relative's reaction rather, of how his death is going to be depicted - as most stories of "Bayani" ends with an abrupt bullet or a machete to the body (about 50 times). I vividly remember reading that he once gave his SONA in a hospital bed in Washington DC because he was fighting TB. While he often had that shiny 20-peso bill image to him, reading books like Nick Joaquin's A Question of Heroes (which this film takes inspiration) suggests a more open to interpretation viewpoint of the politician-statesman. You can write a persuasive essay about it, honestly, and your highschool AP teacher would probably applaud you by choosing either depictions and look at the complexities of the human character and the political environment he had to deal with. Going back to the ending though, you can very much understand the backlash because it really leaned into the creative side of the narrative. But I kinda like it because its a fun thought to have; if MLQ didnt get sick, what would he have done more as his legacy? Depicted as the savvy, charming, trickster of a politician playing "the game of politics" and always trying to get the upper hand on people, I'd like to think that he would've been similar to how Lee Kuan Yew did for Singapore. Similar in character in a lot of ways and tickling his way to almost authoritarian (competitive authoritarianism, that is). At least with the way how the film depicted it. "I am the Philippines" is definitely a bold line to say, but probably not too far off. And the line about "Quezon may not have invented the game, but he sure damn played it well" describes the character perfectly.The film is actually the commentary of Jerold Tarog, the director. He questions Manolo's morality and character because that's how we all should look at historical figures. I remember when Luna came out, everyone was preaching his machismo, especially at the height of Dutertismo. But Tarog probably saw the bad effects of the film and tell us: "Hey, don't worship our heroes." Funny how the film mocks the audience for incorporating the silent film-slide show scenes at points, as if they're trying to tell you "this is how most people probably would've made this film: prim, proper, textbook-like, 'here's all the key highlights of his life and the good he's done, and then he died." Rather, they chose to depict that complex, imperfect, flawed character that I would've been more interested in watching. He's never meant to be seen as a martyr. He's a historical figure, a real person. Is it 100% accurate? I don't know, ask your history teacher. Was it fun to watch? Was the acting great? More importantly, was the film good? All points to: Yes. Yes it was. Last note: MLQ III is right. The film is a horror story about corruption of power, the state of politics today, and the trajectory of Philippine politics from that point on. Makes my arm hair stand up.

the streets said it was old man yaoi.....i was still not prepared for how much it WAS old man yaoi*.........anyway. incredible conclusion to the bayaniverse and perhaps the most emblematic of the entire ethos of the trilogy. lowkey a movie about movies and the power of movies and i love that. powerhouse performance from jericho rosales. tangina gurl ramdam mo talaga yung Performance of it all. the act he puts up according to who he's talking to. the manipulate mansplain manwhore of it all as he leverages friendships and charisma that he puts on with the same ease as one of his impeccably styled suits (bc the suits were incredible). the scene where he plays his favorite game "appointments"? during lq nila ni serging? where he picks roxas to be his rebound boytoy puppet? my favorite visual moment in the movie bc it literally looks like a game. bc it is just a game to him!!! as much as all the poker he plays!!! ika nga nya "its just politics. walang personalan."on that note, as a visual story very fun. i really like the cutting interplay of the campaign films he commissioned vs the "reality" of the movie. is it perhaps heavyhanded and kinda spoonfeeding the audience? yes. but frankly the responses to the previous bayaniverse movies warrant that and they were never subtle in what they were trying to talk about anyway. mon confiado ate and left no crumbs truly. every performance was just really good. delighted at the centrality of nadia's character actually. very fun. arron villaflor and cris villanueva as joven were wonderful. to see how far the naive journalist innocently interviewing heneral luna has come felt very full circle, and as the audience stand in, very poignant. to keep getting let down by our image of the Great (Good) Man who will Definitely solve all our problems this time and yet still fall prey to its allure only to once again get disillusioned and realize the truth too late? dare i say there are few things more filipino than that.kaya siguro gagalet yung apo ni quezon eh. bc the parallels drawn to the current shitshow in the government aren't subtle and perhaps they're unflattering for someone historically revered as a hero but isnt that literally the point of the movies? to bring some nuance and humanity to the flat heroic figures of history? is art not meant to make us question? to provoke even a crumb of critical thought? something we're in dire need of these days. quezon didn't invent the game but he did master it. and perhaps yung pinakaambag nya sa current state of ph politics is that he realized that history is written by the winners. and sometimes all that means is some good framing.ika nga nya: "ang pagkabayani? its all about perception."(*about that gay shit bro that was crazy. i was fully alone in the cinema which is good bc i was losing my shit. mi querido???? serging????? bringing him chocolate and wine??? nagtatampo ka parin?????? the exasperated fondness??????? bro was tryna make sergio jealous via manuel roxas?????? the continuous reference to them being like a couple????????? being WORSE than a couple??????? the DANCE THAT TBA KEEPS POSTING NEW ANGLES OF......diabolical. they said its time for ph historical old man yaoi rpf and i have nothing but respect. anyway. echo and romnick are captaining the ship themselves thats crazy good for them)

fascinating film. clear eyed on its mission on dissecting how we got here and how we're still stuck here but I don't really think it does enough to condemn the actual system (capitalism and colonialism) that allows for the rise of populists. What I got most from this is I think Tarog is frustrated by the success of Luna and how it led us even just a tiny bit to electing the kind of person he warns us with in this film (TWICE IN A ROW, this god forsaken country man) given how much the framing device of this is about an alternate cut of what are essentially propaganda films. I think these films are really about the disillusionment of a man may it be Joven or Tarog himself in the Filipino project while I think it's valid (and I do share the sentiment a lot of the time) I don't really know if it's the sentiment we need in this moment considering his ideals about reviving the idea of national mythmaking through Philippine cinema. I hope people take something else from here other than, oh all politicians are the same and it is what it is, I hope they at least realize that the powers that be are fallible (Quezon eventually runs out of time) and that we see through their bullshit and that populists are really fucking bad for "freedom" and that we should get rid of them by hook or by crook although the film doesn't really go there because history didn't go there. Overall it's fascinating stuff. Really loved how propulsive his direction and editing are, the energy of this thing is just really great. The performances are impeccable and I didn't know Rosales had something like this in him.

Possibly one of my most engaging watches this year. Instead of picking up from where Goyo and Heneral Luna left off, Quezon abandons the tragic hero's tale of its predecessors and instead explores, for lack of a better word, its titular character's descent into madness and depravity. It's less a biopic and more of a character study that relishes in the drama of its narrative without needing to wink and nudge at the viewer. There's a lot of standout performances here, but Iain Glen, Romnick Sarmiento, and Jericho Rosales really stand head and shoulders above the rest in a very talented cast. Glen and Sarmiento especially bring a lot to their characters' tables with microexpressions that elevate already stellar performances. Sarmiento's facial expressions by themselves are strong enough to constitute dialogue. Rosales, meanwhile, really puts the larger-than-life aspects of the titular character at the forefront of his performance and just exudes the kind of charisma you would expect a man like Quezon to have. As much as I would've liked to see what TJ Trinidad would've done with the role had he not been replaced, it's hard to see how anyone other than Rosales was the best choice.On top of that, the movie pulls very little back in the way of punches. Very few characters are portrayed in a positive manner and it's the clashes between these strong personalities that make this picture so interesting to me. The film also uses these clashes as a Trojan horse for some scathing social commentary that, while on-the-nose, hardly ever crosses the line of being egregious or preachy.The visual and stylistic homages to Fritz Lang's works, especially, were the cherry on top for me. Brava.

Itâ€™s been a big year for Philippine cinema, and what could make it even bigger than a film about politics and power? Quezon dives deep into Manuel L. Quezon â€” his legacy, his triumphs, and all his mess and contradictions. The film portrays him as charming and eloquent, a political game player, and manipulative at times â€” without ever romanticizing him. Itâ€™s insane how the political landscape back then mirrors so much of what we still see today. The film serves as a fascinating tribute to one of the countryâ€™s most dominant and complex figures.The cinematography and editing are stunning. It's an ambitious step forward for Philippine cinema and a huge achievement in craft. The script, dialogue, and even the incorporation of silent film techniques beautifully capture the era. The acting is top-notch. Jericho Rosales, Romnick Sarmenta, and Mon Confiado delivered powerful performances!Overall, Quezon offers a sharp, compelling glimpse into the man behind the myth while holding a mirror to our present-day politics. Itâ€™s timely, daring, and deeply resonant. People really need to see this. What a great film.

This film for me is such a refresher because unlike the previous films about MLQ, it challenges the pedestal that he has been put on, which I believe is essential when we discuss important figures in our history. I think a lot of us (myself included) often fall into the trap of patronizing our heroes to the point that we romanticize them through the legacies that they have built. This was very much true for me, specifically with Heneral Luna (Naalala ko grabe yung galit ko kay Aguinaldo nung una kong napanood yung Heneral Luna na movie hahaha).While some may see this film as overtly negative and borderline slanderous against MLQ, I see it as a way to challenge the longstanding beliefs and notions regarding him. It pushes people to rethink our history, to be more critical, and to ask questions about what really happened in the past.And of course, the biggest elephant of them all is the connection between the past and the present. This is not just a historical film; it is also a social commentary about the current political climate we have right now. We can make the analogy of how the things from the past never really changed up to the present day. It merely evolved, adapted, and thrived. It persisted because the people in power willed it so.Going back to the film, we can also see how the concept utang na loob played a big part in ultimately shaping MLQâ€™s politicking. How it was first used on him and eventually, how he used this to take the reigns of our country.â€œYou either die young as a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become the villain.â€In essence, MLQ wouldnâ€™t have survived that long in the landscape of Philippine politics had he not conformed to the games being played on the floors of its administration. His good intentions, as genuine as it might have been when he first started, nevertheless was inevitably consumed by the environment he was in. Truly, it was a world of â€œeat or be eatenâ€.
Effective in its message that no politician deserves absolute glory

"Independencia!"A bit confused with the overall structure of how Quezon's life was narrated with this film. But kudos to the improvement of cinematography all throughout the "Bayani-verse", this has definitely had more oomph and a more modern visual style. As for the story-telling, they were a bit of skips or creative juggling on the timelines, some might have been too fast for the viewers to understand or follow through. I do like how some of the issues or social commentary here relates to what we are now facing in the current day politics of the Philippines. What I also like is that they added these cut parts of silent-film era of adding pieces to the puzzle of how Quezon raised to power during his time. The technique they used is spot on, on how old films were shown.

I really enjoyed this movie! I loved the timing and editing especially when they were used to play up the comedy or the tension. The non-linear storytelling was kinda confusing but that might be a skill issue; everything DID end up making more sense in the end. I really admire the casting for these films! Gets ko na kung bakit crush ng dati naming kasambahay si Jericho Rosales. Mon Confiado as Emilio Aguinaldo is just SO good. The previous films in this series showed Aguinaldo for the traitor that he was but then this movie almost had me sympathizing with him damn. Until this movie, I only ever knew Quezon as the mukha sa P20, yung ama ng wikang pambansa, namatay dahil sa TB. But this movie, which his grandson got angry over, showed a new side of Quezon, or rather many sides as a trapo and balimbing. I thought this might be the last in this series, so I'm holding out hope for Magsaysay. Joven Hernando, you poor and brave jaded journalist!

We were supposed to do this at Amazon but what happened happened. Despite everything Iâ€™m lucky to have read three drafts of this and a treatment of what would have been its structure were it a series, and came in to the theater just to marvel at how Jerrold would pull this off. He pulled this off wonderfully, of course, with humor and aplomb. The script wasnâ€™t as funny as it turned out to be on the screen, and kudos to Jerrold for seeing our government for the farce it is. Seeing Jericho play Quezon initially felt put on, but by the end you believe heâ€™s the living, breathing embodiment of the 50 peso bill. Cris Villanueva puts some weight and character into the everpresent Joven. Jorah Mormont is a great Leonard Wood despite the accent. Karylle is always great and is missed on the big screen (follow her on Letterboxd). I really love Romnick as Roxas. And our dear beloved Mon Confiado, the survivor of the trilogy, plays Emilio Aguinaldo as the same person with the fire behind his eyes fully extinguished. Itâ€™s a painful portrayal, and will make you feel bad about all his shenanigans from the prior two films. End of the day Iâ€™m just grateful that during this time, what feels like such a low point for Philippine cinema, Jerrold continues to create his films about our flawed history, filled with stories of deluded strongmen, inexperienced boy generals and manipulative power players. He holds a mirror to our society that most people in power, heroesâ€™ grandchildren included, donâ€™t want to see. But when Leonard Wood talks about politicians using diplomatic trips as an excuse for family vacations and Filipinos not ready for independence with their infighting and greed, everything feels so eerily timely. Then you realize thatâ€™s the way itâ€™s always been. Me: Question: matatapos na yung trilogy mo. Unlike Heneral Luna and Goyo, Quezon did not show any form of physical violence; rather, it portrayed violence through the use of words. Storytelling-wise, it was quite okay for me, but I think there are a lot of areas that could be improved. As someone who doesnâ€™t appreciate slow-paced movies, Quezon felt really boring to me at the beginning. Nadiaâ€™s role as a storyteller throughout the film also felt somewhat messyâ€”but then again, it allows the audience to form their own opinions and perspectives on the narratives and realities she presented during Quezonâ€™s term.In both Heneral Luna and Goyo, Joven served as a symbol of youthâ€”the hopeful defender of our countryâ€™s future and independence. In Quezon, however, he symbolized how people might abandon their morals because of the selective facts presented to themâ€”facts that politicians carefully curate for their own benefit. Joven still represented hope for the Philippines, because even though he strayed from the beliefs he once fought for, he eventually came to understand how manipulative and power-hungry politicians can be. This idea was further emphasized by Miguel Laureanoâ€™s retirement, which symbolized the shift in political climate and the changing perception of the masses.The movie reflected the bitter reality of our current political stateâ€”it mirrored how Filipinos tend to be selective about what kinds of change and movement they are willing to support. As we moved on from Quezonâ€™s term, we should have experienced growth and improvement, yet we did not. The film illustrated how our political system remains trapped in a constant loop, where we continue to vote for and campaign for politicians who ultimately serve Western interests rather than our own.

The controversy over this film has been severely overblown. Yes, it is satire. And just because it is, doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s a joke that we canâ€™t take seriously. I thought it was pretty good, itâ€™s very well made with a really good performance by Jericho Rosales. My main issue is the character of Joven and his daughter. The use of a fictional journalist is interesting but I feel like him being so involved in the story was too much. I would've preferred him being more like a fly on the wall than being directly a part of the story.

ok after collecting all of my thoughts, ang husay mong tunay, quezon (2025) ! ipinakita mo kung gaano kadumi ang eleksyon at pulitika sa bansa, kung gaano lapastanganin ng kapangyarihan ang pilipinas mula pa noon. sa paggamit ng pwesto para manlamang ng kapwa, mula sa pagpapasara ng isang kilalang publikasyong alerta, sa pagpapasara ng bukid ni aguinaldo, sa pang-iikot sa batas para magmukhang malinis sa madla, at kung paanong ipamukhang mangmang ang mga pilipino.it's scary how politicians acts like this until this day of 2025, hindi tayo natututo, hindi tayo umuusbong bilang bayan, hindi tayo umaangat bilang isang mamamayanâ€“dahil sa mga katulad ni quezon. it's truly a masterpiece, salamat sa pagsasabuhay ng kwento ni quezon at magmumulat pa lalo sa mata ko at sa paninindigan ko. salamat bayaniverse, isa kang tunay na napakagaling na likha.

cinematography was on POINTTT i love the little symbolisms, especially during the scenes where they have to go up and down that one split staircase (the subtle smugness of quezon once he says that he'll be resigning from the position of senate president knowing damn well he won't and proceeding to take one step higher on the staircase than osmeÃ±a ğŸ¤Œ)i will say though, the dialogue itself was... strangely unnatural. the mouthful of historical references that they shove into some of the lines makes it very obvious that they only wanted to spoonfeed unknowing viewers with the needed context which sadly, cheapens the initial quality of the film..but overall, the portrayal of political figures and their messiness was beautifully done. it wasn't too broody that it disinterests the audience but it's grounded enough that it proves itself to have something substantial to say about mindless politics; what does it really mean to be free? and are we ready to take up that responsibility?

quick fire thoughts,-movie could've been a tighter 1hr 40 min movie. cut out the first wife subplot-i love the early parts, it felt so wes anderson surpringly, not in his asthetics but more int he spirit of having charicatures and very stage like presentation. - i love how the poltical game is represented like chess, but the excution of using whatever editing software to zoom in, and 5x the footage was bad. good idea but the excution was not able to realise it-personally i would've liked the quirky exaggeration to be heighted further. quezon at times feels more like walt disney, a micky mouse figure that is not a person. this is a good thing it adds to the political satire. - the framing device of using old movie reels to lead into flashbacks was a bit sloppy, at times you'd forget this framing device it's inconsitent. even the 3 act structure feels like it's all put out too quickly. the film feels like it's torn between two tones. but at times it balances it well, espcially with the parade scene at the end with quezon and emillo's parades being contrasted espcially with it's color grading. could've been better but it's good.for this film i ate bottled ice tea, and drank sour cream popcorn with less butter added than i originally asked for. i brought with me a party size popcorn that we bought from the cementary during all souls day, i added my own clarified butter which was good. i wish the bottled ice tea was cold. but at least it didnt make me go to the CR 2x

I rarely see Jericho Rosales in films but I think he does a good job capturing Quezon and the way people talk back in the late 1920s-30s. Of course I have to applaud the production and costume design! Itâ€™s excellent and if I remember my fashion history well, I think they did a good job at depicting the way Filipinos & especially Filipino women dressed back then. I also LOVE the format they chose to tell the story to stay true to the times, thru the silent films and then the 1920s-30s visual aesthetics. That aspect was so fun I love it so much!!!!!!! Anyway, itâ€™s interesting to see how they portrayed Quezon because I vaguely remember how he was portrayed as a good President back in my elementary Philippine History lessons, how we briefly touched upon his â€œachievementsâ€. But since they say that this depiction was backed by historians, public facts and documents then I think they really did a good job of humanizing him. He wasnâ€™t just a shallow historical figure from the recent past anymore, we get to see his flaws & his motivations. This is great!Leaving the cinema just made me kinda depressed tbh because it just reminded me of my PI 100 class. The fact that we have such a repetitive case of betrayal, corruption, greed for money & power . . . . lagi nalang nananalo yung mga taong nasa matataas na posisyon na inuuna ang kanilang sariling interes imbis na maglungkod para sa bansa at para sa mga Pilipino, pumpublikong serbisyo. hayss

i remember quezon being one of the many names i had to memorize for some 4th grade exam alongside his contributions to the jones act and the tydings-mcduffie act. it was only until i became invested in historical movies that i decided to watch the bayaniverse, and it was in this trilogy where i started to look back and revisit my perspective on our national heroes. when we look at history, the act of calling someone a hero or a villain is very reductive, as it ignores the nuances of their decisions and their distinct worldviews and beliefs. the philippines is not exempt from this at all. in the context of the bayaniverse, these people (luna, goyo, quezon) are inept and egotistical at best, and downright criminal at worst, but put them in a movement, and you have the spirit of the filipino revolution, proud and waving the flag. and despite their flaws, that does not erase the efforts they've done for an independent republic.tarog, with quezon, aimed to showcase both his flaws and his accomplishments in a way that piques our interest and to go to our local library and read up on our history. we are directly anchored in through joven and his family, and through him, we get to interact with the true nature of quezon, one that, just as tarog intended, is not displayed in bullet text or powerpoint. he is a con man who thrives in confidence and does whatever is necessary, because to him, politics is a game of chess. he anticipates, he strategizes, and takes advantage of weakness. he is thrust into a system that benefits those in power, and considering his eagerness to satiate his thirst for power, he uses that system to gain complete control of his circle and of the country.its use of satire and the bravado of 1920s silent film aesthetic at certain points complements the big personality of quezon, immediately making it the most unique out of the trilogy, where the prior films were conventional war epics, rather showcasing the action of politics than the action of bloodshed, but it remains as violent and intense as the previous films, but what makes quezon stand out is that despite its lens (not borrowed from nepomuceno!), the situations facing the country remain significantly relevant. the constant trips costing filipino taxpayers millions? the fact that we have more politicians than public servants? infighting between two major political players? i forgot who said it, but they mentioned that quezon became the blueprint for modern day trapos, and i can see it! he possesses many of the traits that make up most of our senate, he's a cheat, a liar, and an opportunist! and that's what makes our national heroes so much more interesting. in one way or another, they are not faultless, nor are they necessarily bad people. despite all my shit talk on quezon, the one thing i'll give him credit for was his love for the country, his means justify the ends and he DELIVERS, at the cost of his morality and friendships.the chameleon will always fit in with anyone, but in the end, it will end up with no one, and that is the price one shall pay to become the chameleon.i got a good deal though, it was 13 dollars for one ticket? good shit

Kaya pala nagalit si Gov. Helen Tan at kapamilya niya cause they didnâ€™t show a single redeemable trait of Quezon here, which honestly I kind of liked. Heâ€™s always portrayed as this larger-than-life president who accomplished so much. And although his flaws are in the history books, theyâ€™re rarely emphasized in schools. This movie finally showed that side of him. Although they still showed his contributions for the Filipino people, it was overshadowed by the scheming, womanizing, manipulative traits, and that lowkey god complex side of him, at least with how he was depicted in the movie.Heâ€™s still undeniably a great president who did a lot for the country, but itâ€™s good that we donâ€™t over-romanticize or idolize political figures. I just wish they also covered his actions during his term and during the Japanese invasion. It wouldâ€™ve made a stronger conclusion and could have highlighted more of his contributions.As a Quezonian, this movie slapped. It honestly validated all the shady things Iâ€™ve researched about him before for a contest about.... well, him. Gets ko din naman bakit madami na offend, but yun nga we should also be aware of his flaws, and not glorify him too much. Overall great cast and great performances.

Echo will surely enjoy picking up trophies for next year's awards derby. A grand slam feat for Best Actor. I could have given QUEZON a perfect score of 5 but the conflict here possibly to give it more cinematic highlight aside from that toss coin sequence... we didn't see his accomplishments. He was presented as a womanizer, traitor friend and a political manipulator that brought controversy thrown to the cast and crew by one of the grandson of Quezon during the Q&A. Technically this is the most polished among the Bayaniverse which includes HENERAL LUNA & GOYO. A film like this comes as a manna from heaven since big budget period epic comes only in a blue moon for theatrical viewing. Kudos to TBA, cast and crew! I I only knew Leonard Wood as one of the roads in the City of Pines, this one gave me the curiosity the best time now to dig our history.And the fantastic ensemble cast along with Jericho Rosales includes Mon Confiado as Aguinaldo. How about a back to back win next year for Best Supporting Actor? Let time will tell if QUEZON will be on the league of our period epic classics like JOSE RIZAL, ORO PLATA MATA & GANITO KAMI NOON PAANO KAYO NGAYON but for the meantime let's be grateful that this film manage to keep Philippine Cinema alive at least for the meantime.
