I watched Quezon yesterday in the cinemas. The movie leans heavily on the negative aspects of Manuel L. Quezonâ€™s characterâ€”some of which are based on conjecture and lack sufficient historical evidence to be accepted as truth. For example, there is a scene portraying voters booing Emilio Aguinaldo during his presidential campaign, supposedly orchestrated by Quezon. There is no record of this ever happening.The film presents an unbalanced portrayal of the Philippinesâ€™ first president, further complicated by a fictional subplot involving made-up characters: journalist Jevon Hernando and his filmmaker daughter, Nadia, who produce campaign videos for Quezonâ€™s presidential run while secretly creating â€œmore honestâ€ versions of each one.I didnâ€™t quite understand the purpose of this subplot, except perhaps to draw parallels with the current political climate. The campaign videos felt like an early version of a â€œtroll farm.â€ In that sense, the film invites viewers to reflect on the prevalence of â€œfake newsâ€ and how even legitimate journalists can become complicit in the myth-making that surrounds political figures.The film puts forward the idea that â€œdemocracyâ€ in the Philippines has never been the real deal because of problematic leaders such as Manuel Quezon, and that the system has always been broken from the start. I think itâ€™s a motivating sentiment; however, the message becomes contrived when retroactively applying it to Quezonâ€™s story.It presents what on the surface appears to be a compelling question: What does it mean when a historical film uses a 21st-century lens to moralize the past? However, I personally disagree with this treatment of history. I believe history should be explored as unfamiliar terrainâ€”something distinct from our present time. Otherwise, how could we genuinely learn anything from it? Imposing a modern framework of social mediaâ€“driven politics onto the past flattens historical complexity, especially when many Filipinos donâ€™t have access to in-depth historical education or materials outside of school.The storyâ€”not just of Manuel Quezonâ€™s life, but of all Filipinos involved in the journey toward Philippine independence, from the formation of the Senate and Congress to the election of the first presidentâ€”could have offered an inspiring message. Instead, all of this is portrayed as nothing but a sham. The film minimizes the work that Filipino figures did to win our independence by focusing only on the unsavory details of Quezonâ€™s life, such as his love-hate relationship with OsmeÃ±a and his ploy to get Governor-General Leonard Wood removed from office. One of the filmâ€™s early fictional chapters is titled Quezon vs. Hernando: A Noble Lie, in which Quezon and Hernando debate the concept of â€œnoble liesâ€ using a quote from Plato. Quezon â€œlosesâ€ the argument simply because Hernando can name-drop more philosophers. Many scenes like this follow, reducing Quezon to a caricatureâ€”an exaggeratedly naÃ¯ve and shallow version of himself.Because our history is often told through the lens of our colonizers, mainly Americans, Filipinos have long had a weak sense of the value of freedom and independence. We have been taught to believe that we are not ready to govern ourselvesâ€”and perhaps never will be. The film includes Quezonâ€™s famous line: â€œI would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by the Americans.â€ In a more balanced portrayal, this line could have carried real gravitas. But given the filmâ€™s cynical treatment of Quezon, it instead becomes further evidence of his supposed incompetence.This film could have offered audiences a meaningful, alternative way to engage with our history. Instead, it mimicked the very dynamics of social media, reducing historical events into digestible, sensationalized drama. Audiences should ask questions while watching the movie, such as: Is there any genuine historical basis for the scene in which Manuel Quezon asks Vicente Madrigal for a blank check to fund his presidential campaign? What was the purpose of showing a completely fabricated conversation between a drunk Leonard Wood and Manuel Quezon?I also took issue with the portrayal of Emilio Aguinaldo as Quezonâ€™s more â€œcredibleâ€ rival. The movie pits Quezon and Aguinaldo against each other, going so far as to fabricate or misrepresent events to exaggerate their rivalryâ€”such as showing Quezon canceling Aguinaldoâ€™s pension during his run against him and framing the loss of Aguinaldoâ€™s farm as a personal attack. Neither of these are based on fact. It is well-documented that Aguinaldo ordered the executions of Andres Bonifacio and Antonio Luna. These are not Quezonâ€™s political inventionsâ€”they are part of the historical record. Yet the movie invents an entirely fictional subplot involving Pedro Janolino, who reaches out to Joven Hernando to reveal that Aguinaldo ordered him to kill General Antonio Luna. He is later revealed to be Quezonâ€™s sergeant-at-arms who planted the testimony to sabotage Aguinaldo. In truth, there really was a Pedro Janolino, and he did kill General Luna. He died before Quezon ran for president, and it was Panteleon Garcia who later revealed that Aguinaldo ordered Lunaâ€™s murder.Unfortunately, I didnâ€™t find the film well-executed overall. The acting was uneven, with the exception of Jericho Rosales (Quezon) and Mon Confiado (Aguinaldo). The fictional film-within-a-film subplot featured unlikable, underdeveloped characters, and the â€œsilent movieâ€ aesthetic came across as contrived rather than clever. The production design was also disappointing. The U.S. colonial period was a stylish eraâ€”this is evident from the films and photographs of the timeâ€”yet the costumes, especially for the women, lacked both elegance and authenticity.In the end, I couldnâ€™t understand the filmâ€™s motive in diminishing Quezonâ€™s legacy. It seemed told through a distinctly pro-American lens: the Filipino masses are depicted as naÃ¯ve and gullible, unable to grasp what â€œindependenceâ€ truly means, while figures like Sergio OsmeÃ±a and Manuel Roxas are reduced to mere sidekicks without agency or depthâ€”an unfair portrayal of these important historical figures.Ultimately, the film misses an important opportunity. Instead of offering a richer understanding of our nationâ€™s early struggles for independence, it relies on cynicism, convenient narratives, and present-day parallels that oversimplify historyâ€”a treatment that is both disrespectful to Quezon and his descendants and intellectually irresponsible. That half the movieâ€™s plot rests on a fabricated premise should be a sign for audiences to approach it critically. Quezonâ€™s story deserves a more nuanced, intelligent retellingâ€”one that trusts its audience to think deeply, not one that panders to the fleeting attention span of social media.

I can see why people would criticize this film for not representing the historical figures for all the actions they've done no matter how good or bad. But pieces of art, which this film is (regardless of quality), are meant to tell a thematic story.For what it is, a film and not a documentary, it uses historical figures as symbols to tell a story of political games and showmanship. They are not who they were in history but are instead used as a backdrop for the inner workings of politics still prevalent to this day. The addition of Joven Hernando as a fictional character, other than being a narrative device, is a clear intention of the story being fictional, not historical, even if his existence being too fantastical at times.Yes, it can be dangerous to represent a historical event/s and handwave all inaccuracies as necessary for drama. You can even call this film straight up propaganda since it aims to tell a certain message with regards to politics, but it still functions as a piece of art. There is a risk of audiences viewing this dramatization as historical fact. A risk that no amount of "fictionalized" disclaimers can make people believe it to be otherwise.Do I believe this film shouldn't have been made for the lack of historical context it portrays? No. Without this film, I don't think a lot of Filipinos would know who Leonard Wood is. It ignites interests about the historical figures and leads people to seek out the facts themselves. Not a lot of people, me included, were aware of all the shit Wood did as Governor-General prior to this film.I didn't rate this film 3.5/5 for its accuracy, but instead for its pacing and tendency to read between the lines for you. Otherwise, it has great cinematography and a huge improvement in production value compared to Jerrold Tarog's previous films.

This is very much a Bayaniverse entry without a single gunshot fired and the blood staining the chests of military men, its framework based on the idea of the camera being the real militant weapon of the times, and the truth is in the edit, despite Tarog rendering the device no weight. There is simply no richness to be dug from ur-text of Quezonâ€”its notions on the gamification of governance blowing cobwebs off a tired and worn out thesis as its attempts to doll up the friction within his praxis end up flat (why the hell is Aguinaldo suddenly so scared of placards). And so it becomes all the more revealing when Tarog stayed silent during the meltdown of a Quezon descendant at their Powerplant Q&A: a silence that reveals a spinelessness unbecoming of a filmmaker who has made the Definitive Trilogy on behalf of the Filipino Peopleâ„¢. A funny nugget of irony now when Quezon clocks Joven as a hypocrite: the witness who records, but never intervenes.

I did not care for the kind of simplistic depiction of political backroom talks. Although itâ€™s a scathing recounting of Quezon as a flawed man, it felt like they did not go deeper as to the extent of corruption, its cover up and the real intentions.I wonder now if my opinion on the acting would change if I were satisfied with how the story of Quezon was tackled.

Jerrold Tarrog has the magic of making you question history while still allowing you to remain enjoying the film. It makes you want to seek more information about it. It makes you see this people who we have always known since youth, in a new light. But having said that, I still think that Goyo, among the three is his best.

Luna is a heroes hero, while Goyo and Quezon have little to no redeeming qualities in their portrayal. Important still that these â€œgreat menâ€ of Philippine history are deconstructed and demystified in a trilogy of pretty decent (or maybe better yet, palateable) movies. This last one feels a bit too long, its titular Quezon a bit too villainous, but a watchable film nonetheless.

Politics in the Philippines has always been a cycle of promises, lies, and abuse of power. This movie shows that Filipino politicians of the past are no different from those we have today. It shows us how we are deceived by lies, how we often choose the worst option when making decisions, and how â€œutang na loobâ€ continues to shape our choices. The filmâ€™s pacing feels unique, almost like an American movie. It focuses on exposing Quezonâ€™s wrongdoings, which explains why his grandson reacted strongly, but as they say, history doesnâ€™t lie. I did find it hard to separate fact from fiction, especially since the place where Emilio was cornered in the movie wasnâ€™t the same as in real life. That can be misleading for viewers, especially students. Nonetheless, I really enjoyed the film; I didnâ€™t even notice how quickly time passed while watching it.

Itâ€™s a pretty straightforward historical drama, chronicling the rise of a political leader and charting the path for independence for The Philippines. Iâ€™ll acknowledge that it doesnâ€™t seem to be a shameless puff piece, and it acknowledges Quezon as a sort of leader without much personal integrity who focuses more on pragmatism, which perhaps may have been important for his goals, even if he was driven largely by ego. There is some interesting artistic flair with the silent film interpretations, which honestly should have been the entire film.Jericho Rosales is excellent at giving that Charlie Sheen vibe.Itâ€™s a solid film overall even if it does kind of drag with a bunch of political bullshit thatâ€™s admittedly all the same thing of constant backstabbing and alliances, which does sound cool, but itâ€™s a pretty normal historical drama.

Just donâ€™t compare Quezon to the first two films in the trilogy and youâ€™ll find something to admire. It stands on its own as a portrait of power and pride, though at times unsure of which face to show. Jericho Rosales walks a tightrope between conviction and caricature, brilliant one moment, baffling the next. The production looks rich and patriotic, but the story doesnâ€™t quite know what itâ€™s fighting for. It wants to build a hero, but forgets to give him a clear battle. Still, if you let it be its own story, youâ€™ll enjoy the echoes of history and the weight of what it tries to say.

The two sides of the same coin. The admired and the flawed. The good old fashioned politician and the staunch patriot."QUEZON" isn't particularly the film that one may expect from writer-director Jerrold Tarog's "Bayaniverse". The titular hero isn't glorified but examined - with all his strengths and imperfections. History, as rich as it gets, immortalizes the gripping and controversial facets of the beloved statesman that unsurprisingly still echo up to this day.Exceptionally played by Urian winner Jericho Rosales, we get to see the might, influence, charisma, narcissism, lies, and betrayals of Philippines' second president through his acting force and vulnerability. The penchant to roll the classic 4:3 movie aspect ratio in its short films and the interesting camera pans during the Congress election strategies a la chess moves are some of its strong suits. Art and production designs, although a good addition, can be improved to perfectly embody its era. Bearing its creative license, it dramatizes the calculated games and internal conflicts through (at times confusing) non-linear storytelling with hefty dialogues and politicking narratives that can be cut down in exchange for more warranted depictions of political effects to the society under the eight-year regime, apart from showcasing people's ignorance of the very notion of independence. Now that would be more compelling and cathartic. Rosales truly leads the pack but it's indubitable that every featured artist (Romnick Sarmenta, Mon Confiado, Cris Villanueva, Benjamin Alves, Karylle, and even its import Iain Glen to name a few) pours their heart to the material. A call to action in these trying times, may this push us to demand for a better nation.Joven Hernando and Alerta. Plato and Kant. Casey and the Philippines. Heroes are still humans. 3.5/5, folks! "QUEZON" is still playing in Philippine cinemas. #MovieMadness ğŸ‘Š

Our history might be flawed and imperfect, and revisiting it can unravel old wounds, but it defines us who we all are today. Score is amazing too...oh and watch it if you haven't. Changed my perception on the late president... What an ensemble!

an aguinaldo propaganda in the guise of a quezon biopic? this film is really all about perception. how quezon weaponized perception. and most importantly on how this film presents aguinaldo in stark contrast to how he was presented in heneral luna. i hated that aguinaldo presented in the past film but i canâ€™t help but sympathize with him in this one. but this is what this film wants it to be and that â€œaguinaldo propagandaâ€ concludes not only the movie, but the franchise altogether. i kept thinking that maybe there remains in aguinaldo a semblance of heroism especially in that one specific scene where he chose not to introduce quezonâ€™s alleged first wife and just use her as a pawn. or maybe it was the emphasis on how his candidacy for presidency was a mere heed of duty and not out of lust for power. or maybe i felt bad because he was gradually yet loudly stripped of power. or maybe just the culmination of every vengeful act of quezon against him. or maybe itâ€™s just easier to accept him as a lesser evil. the idea of resonating and accepting someone merely because they are a lesser evil is just plain foolishness in theory. even the idea of a â€œlesser evilâ€ just seems to transcend all bounds of rationality. did we bring that idea into conception as a cry for help? a cry for hope? itâ€™s really easier to side with someone. as a country who remains deep in suffering, misery loves company i guess. but is this really all that we deserve? kailan kayo tayo tuluyang titigil magpakaalipin?

'The Noble Lie'. This is one of the lines that resonated with me after watching the film. The mere fact that these traditional politicians boil everything that they do down to this idea of doing questionable means towards a 'good end' is not only narcissistic but also dangerous at best. These people genuinely believe that a lie could be considered 'noble'. Meaning, what is ethically right for them is already skewed, and that conscience no longer plays a role in the crux of their actions. Rosales' Quezon, even at the very end of the film, embodied this rotten mentality, thoroughly absorbed in the idea of being the 'Great Savior' that the Philippines needed for its independence--even at the expense of losing the true meaning of the word.Truly a magnificent end to the 'bayaniverse' trilogy, showcasing a 'war' that is not fought in the front (compared to 'Heneral Luna' and 'Goyo'). A war that is played behind cunning speeches and charming smiles, but is dangerous all the same. Not gonna lie, I thoroughly enjoyed Quezon and Osmena's dynamics (iykyk). Will definitely be watching again.

came for the politics, stayed for the toxic yaoiquezon was a fun yet impactful movie about what it means to be a "bayani" and the dark side of it. it mostly showed quezon and his two sides: the charming hero of the masses and the dirty tactics opportunist that keeps him in the business. i liked the film felt like a play mirroring how quezon was like a showman and despite a lot of creative liberties, they don't miss with the emotional story beats. it is a shame we didnt get more screentime in his term in ww2 (the standardization of the filipino language kinda does deserve its own film) and the positive effect of his accomplishments on the filipino besides morale but with the scope of the movie being really large, im fine with what we have. i think the film is important as it gives younger people a more accessible way to learn about and cultivate an interest in history, myself included.

Quezon clan threatened and hurt by this film shows it is a DAMN GOOD FILM!Kung may halimbawa sa kapangyarihan ng pelikula, isa sa mga ito yun. Isa sa mga huli sa bayani trilogy ni Jerrold Tarog sums everything up. Imahe ni Quezon na akala natin na perpektong tao siya, ay malayo sa katotohanan. Ang mga itinuturing nating bayani ay meron at merong mga kamalian. Pakita sa pelikulang ito na ang pulitiko ay laro lamang ng mga ilan para sa sarili at di para sa tao, di para sa bayan. Ang satirang mapapaisip ka kung and independensya ay tunay o nakatanikala pa tayo sa mga banyaga. Ano nga ba ang independensya sa kasalukuyang panahon ngayon? Kung independensya ay di kalayaan, di tayo malaya. Isang kakaibang pelikula na dapat tuloy pa na pag-usapan ng tao at di lamang ipagbawalan dahil lamang sa pamilyang nakinabang sa imahe na ibinigay sa kanilang ninunong Quezon. Kahit nga si Quezon ay biktima dahil sa pananaw na sumabay at makilaro sa sistema upang sana matupad ang kalayaan. Ngunit nilubog siya hanggang hindi na siya kailangan ng mga banyaga. Patuloy sana ang mga pelikulang ganito. Pagpugay at padayon Jerrold Tarog!!!

I think the film has true promise. Quezon has always been quite a controversial figure of the early fight for true Philippine independence. He did as much good and as much bad if you really think deeply about it BUT the film is just presented in such a dense way.In posits there is true good in Politics.Even sections of actual criticism in the film is really hampered by Tarrog's insistence of the right 'governance'. The lack of a real alternative or an actual in depth conversations that does not really fall into this guise of moral grandstanding is prevalent that it was so eyeroll inducing. You can read philosophies and still be the worst person ever - a college with Liberal Arts make you learn that quickly. If Quezon did not win, what does Aguinaldo can offer in the table that he himself had not done too?Rather film, just villainizes Quezon's insistence to lead. One good example of the film's insistence for moralistic bent but lack of actual 'analysis' is the film's villainization of Quezon's use of his connection.That is what connections are for. To create this dynamic give and take but it oh no, that is bad - because he can make so much campaign materials. It never really delivered on the fact on what would become the Nacionalista Party lead to one of the biggest ultra-majority in the Philippine's History, a familiar sight if anyone has lived to tell in the Duterte era Congress. In fact, the film kinda glosses the fact that this same majority lead the changes in the constitution that inadvertently resulted to the Marcos Dictatorship. In fact, I do think the reason there are many rich families interested in Government is because how they were able to really to enter political spaces during this time. Like for a film that prides itself as critical, it always uses these weak arguments to posit the rather double face attitude of Quezon. I was grasping straws, because it uses the worst criticisms (ad hominems) rather than just actually pulling real punches that is still present in the current Philippine political space. It just bats this idea that Quezon wants the presidency is bad (not really bad), because he wants it no matter what. His machination is bad since he is not truthful about his intention. It literally is true facts. Quezon is a problematic and prolific muckraker, that most of what we hate about Aguinaldo is actually rooted towards his campaign against him. That is attested but a lot of actual paper trails sadly has been destroyed by the war of 45. The film posits that is bad. (not necessarily) but the problem here is that the film also plays out the same muckraking as noble against some of his 'enemies' since they it's not out there. Like come-on now film. That is just plain stupidity at this point. You cannot just make this two sides of the coin when it's practically the same side. I also hate how the film hates Quezon since he is sly about his approach on things but equally loves the American because of their you ready sine clearly the average filipino does not know the word for Independence. THIS SHOULD BE ABOUT THE LEADERS to begin with. Another instance of the film going for the soft analysis over real question of readiness with the leadership. And also, it really gives so much pass for the Americans and how they handled the Philippines, because they are well-meaning apparently. Suddenly, the atrocities is just a side comment here and there. Even Aguinaldo, who could have been more complex as a character himself is just plainly glorified. I just feel there is so much more here that could have been made to make this actually critical in a sense that in actually is talking about things that would still be prevalent in our life and all. On a lighter mode, Good performances though. Echo does well. I personally think certain actors looked closer to the very Hispanized Quezon but has character for it. He kinda performed really well and the cavalcade of supporting role was a welcome surprise. I personally think the film did well visually and editing wise, which is a lot for a local film. The costuming though is really bad - a lot of badly fitted suits. I will still recommend this BUT with a deep reading about Quezon's role in PHI history tbh. It is important to look at this with a more critical eyes since this takes a lot of true issues about Quezon but in a way that feels misguided tbh. (1) Hmmm. Surface level talks about Government leadership. I wish sana within true leaders dapat tbh. DDS sense is tingling.(2) Uy cinema scenes. Pero again this belief that there is only true good and true bad. And true good is not subtle . And by knowing western idealogy.(3) Konfirmed, half glass empty approach and very dds.(4) The American racism is played done here.(5) Also, Tarrog does hate Quezon here. Even a simple political function like Appointment is played against Quezon, because it is his literal job. He has a job to do, what do you mean he has to be true to some kind of moral logic.(6) Soft positive, great style from Tarrog.(7) Sa lahat ng oomff ko walang commentary about how American was never really into the Philippines, or the rather weird anti-independence belief in the film. but posits that murican cares about you and baddie quezon just want to be free.(8) Not the Aguinaldo advocacy in the film. I still have an hour left off this film and this awful and redeemable in my eyes.(9) Ang tanga na nung film. Literal na may political parties and donor ang isang politiko. Your unpopularity with donors/failing party is more of you problem.(10) There is credence on Aguinaldo vs Quezon. I do believe that Aguinaldo even tried to oust his presidency. (Incorrect it was much worst - collaboration with the Japanese). (11) But this feels like too critical to Quezon at all.(12) This is practically me trying to piece my history. Quezon is not the nicest man in all accounts - the film got that right but he pushed the buttons to where our country lead into. Successful or Not. The film is just too damn negative to the point That it rather be friendly to Americans and Aguinaldo and make them a densely woo is mee characters. (13) Aguinaldo being shocked that people hate after getting a bunch of KKK members death. Kkk is not the same klub from USA, btw.(14) This last section that heavily focuses on Quezon in his final days is so much better. It is a true character study that does not need grandstanding good or bad morality. Talaga namern.

Glad TBA had the budget to export Iain Glen to give an Off-Broadway theatre performance that only serves as a functional foil for a domineering Filipino icon. Speaking of, Rosales thankfully did not rely on the heroic gravitas of John Arcilla's General Luna and playful charm of Paulo Avelino's Goyo. Instead, he leans on the spiteful energy and conniving instincts of a Peter Sellers character, which fits on the pseudo-satirical bite that this Bayaniverse entry tries to achieve.It is not the best of the three. (In fact, it is the most eyebrow-raising but liberating of them.) Yet, if it spawns discussion of what is truth or fiction, satire or reality, heroism or populism, and identity or heritage, then it more than succeeds its intentions or un-intentions.2025 Movie Diary #81

I was surprised to see this at amc, although with only 10am or 10pm showings, so I showed up to the morning movie with breakfast and the other Filipinos of NYC.This is last of director Jerrod Tarog's trilogy exploring the mythology behind Filipino "national heroes," and while I haven't seen the first two, I plan to watch them soon. I am still a beginner in Filipino film, and this was the first time I have seen the American colonial period depicted onscreen. It was very interesting to me, as this time period is the topic of my dissertation. The film was really a character study of Quezon, and did not shy away from being critical.

The third installment of the Bayani-verse franchise yet again provides a compelling portrayal of another pivotal figure in Philippine history. Jericho and Karylle really stood out in their roles as President Manuel L. Quezon and First Lady Aurora Quezon. I particularly enjoyed the unraveling of the Aguinaldo vs. Quezon showdown in 1935, a satisfying karmic payback for the atrocities Aguinaldo did in the past. Understandably, the movie was not as action packed as its predecessors given that its events occurred post-Philippine revolution. But I found the movieâ€™s exposition of the political drama at that time to have sufficiently made up for the lack of gunshots and wars as a backdropWhile the movie is set in the â€˜20s-â€˜30s, â€œQuezonâ€ poignantly mirrors the patronage and personality politics that continue to fester our country today. It ultimately makes one realize that our nationâ€™s forefathers are as equally to be blamed, if not more, for the sorry state of our government today. Note: There is a post-credit scene!

This third bayaniverse installment is more creative and whimsical. It's fitting to the message that the movie is trying to make about powerful men's greed that shaped the beginning of our republic (characterized by choreography, a performance, and ultimately a game where Filipinos lose). We feel more directly the decision to make the film allude to our current political landscape where media becomes a tool in dividing the people. I don't think people should take this as autobiographies of our "bayani" because this film is not just about Quezon but equally the beginnings of a Philippine government that the people deal with today. It's a reflection of our current conditions and the reasons why independence is still a thing our politicians utter but the people never fully grasp. I wished they added Filipino translations to the film within this film though.

Itâ€™s very ambitious. Though it made a valiant attempt, I think it got lost in trying to tell the 30+ year story of the most powerful Filipino 2nd only to Ferdie. Malakas yung opening niya, pero as the screentime went on, naging paulit ulit nlng yung character beat ni Quezon. I think eto talaga yung kahinaan ng â€œBayaniverseâ€. Though deep and well acted, ultimately 2D lng yung mga main characters. The ending was disappointing. Rinush yung â€œtragedyâ€ ni Quezon to a single scene. It felt less like a story and more just a chronology/ documentary, which is the danger nmn of all biopics. Still, it was a fun watch. The smallest attention to detail (like 48 stars lng yung US flag not 50ğŸ˜) kept me hooked since it showed na it was made with passion, nde lng for the cheap jokes/ caricatures of history. If they ever make a Marcos biopic, i hope they learn from the shortcomings of Quezon.

I'm confident in the production's handling of historical accuracy, and one can only wish the production team well, hoping the highest sense of responsibility was employed to achieve that benchmark.Technically, this film is no jokeâ€”it's genuinely strong. Pulling off the production requirements for historical films is incredibly difficult, but what amazes me about director Jerrold Tarog is his profound sense of vision. It is creative, yet direct enough to clearly tell the narrative to a broad audience.Narrative-wise, the "film within a film" trope is a good idea, though it needs some polishing to make the 'buddy and soul' arc more impactful. Despite needing that refinement, it remains a highly creative approach to the story.While I struggle to engage during the very first few minutes, from my lens, this is a great film. It is strong enough to celebrate the Bayaniverse's impact and secure its future.

I think Jericho Rosales did such a compelling Quezon - and his chemistry with Romnick Sarmienta was on fire! This movie, contrary to the extreme reactions of some of Quezonâ€™s descendants, actually deepens the former presidentâ€™s characterization beyond merely being the â€˜Commonwealth presidentâ€™ and the â€˜Father of the national language.â€™ The era Quezon lived in was unlike any other, and its politicians were complex, multifaceted characters navigating personal ambitions along with the demands of governing a fledgling nation. Jerrold Tarog must be commended for his continued examination of the nationâ€™s founding fathers - and this is a fitting, albeit unofficial, conclusion to his â€˜Bayaniverseâ€™ trilogy.

All that for what, shits and giggles?I honestly am very disappointed by this movie. How was this movie PG, there were swear words every five seconds and smoking in every room?Film makers that continue to fumble when they have a book, a short story, a myth, or literally HISTORY, as reference material continues to baffle me. What a waste of resources and potential.These events happened already. Why the need to add fictional elements for thematic purposes? Was adding fictional character/s necessary, if their goal was to educate our generation of who Quezon really was? And why include flashbacks inside the movie, when we are already looking back into the past? It adds confusion as to where we are in the plot. I did not like the ugly art deco designs in the flashback scenes and as part of the office design. The over contoured faces. Using â€œHallelujah Chorusâ€ as background music during the signing of the Tydings-McDuffie Act was tasteless. Please try to be more imaginative next time.American characters (like Wood) being portrayed as morally upright in contrast with Quezonâ€™s portrayal of character should be talked about more. It implies white supremacy and colonial mentality. Letâ€™s not do that all over again :)There was a scene where they brought out Quezonâ€™s first wife for five seconds, for what? Was the goal to empower women or to further impose traditional gender roles where women are pushed to the sidelines? She was dismissed, shrugged from the plot. Please do better next time.This movie had the potential to call out the dirty elections, spoils system, traditional politics, systematic corruption, and imperialism. The very same issues they faced (or should I say reinforced?) before that we still face today. While I do commend the morally stained portrayal of Quezon as it serves as a lesson to not idolize individuals (especially government officials). However, the public may be misled to believe this fictional plot points that are conveniently dramatic. We should not tolerate or promote historical distortion in media. It would be so much better to simply provide the public a historical film that adheres to historical documents and facts.Ps. These are just my opinions. This is a free and independent nation after all (see what I did there? hehe). Pps. I need someone to give me flowers and chocolates after each fight too. ğŸ˜

gets ko na yung nagsabing oppenheimer tagalog to... HAHAHAHAH as far as mainstream pinoy cinema goes, this is a pretty great takedown of the idea of the "great man" as told in the history textbooks that we grew up with. the act of framing manuel quezon's shenanigans in his rise to power as one of the seeds that bore our nation's problems in the present is a pretty brave and bold move for a big budget, mainstream studio film to take, especially in the context of our local cinema. what i think makes quezon work so well is how, unlike the previous two films, it still plots out a clear narrative without losing sight of its unifying thread despite chronicling more than decade's worth of history.the unfortunate caveat to all of this is, of course, the loss of focus on other significant political and social players during this time, such as the sakdalista movement, as well as the downplaying of the strength and significance of the presidential campaign of gregorio aglipay, who himself won two provinces, despite the insignificance that the film portrays him with.despite all that, for what it is, jerrold tarog's quezon is still one of the most exciting filipino releases in recent memory, and the inevitable role it will play in the further reassessment of the way we've learned our history and the eventual reckoning with it will be one that i will be watching out for.

Out of all the films in this trilogy, I think Quezon captures the thesis Tarog's take on the filipino hero the best. Comparing it to Luna and especially Goyo, Quezon seems to be more overt with its critique on filipino politics and the filipino people as spectators of what goes on in our society. Though, seemingly with the other films in this trilogy, its message is served to its audience on a silver platter (some would say very preachy) but I guess it's a hard responsibility to take as a directior especially with how a lot of people took Luna's messaging. So in a way that proves the message of the movie? How could the filipino understand freedom if they are deprived of learning about it? also the performances were so good, Jericho Rosales' charisma and his ability to look so scary and eerie in the most tense situations *chefs kiss* in another note, teasing magsaysay in a post credit scene like the next solo movie in the marvel cinematic universe is so funny.

rewatched quezon with the fam and now i have a whole new thing to rant about HAKSJSSJkasi otw home, my dad was talking about how quezon was made out to be the villain when he technically didnt do anything illegal, he just called in some favors, compared to aguinaldo who was said to have killed luna and bonifaciobut bruhh thats not the point of the film... cuz who fucking cares if what quezon did was illegal, the point was that it was morally wrong and manipulative and untruthful in what he claimed himself to be to his voters and to the publicthe point is that the foundation of philippine politics is based on morally wrong and informal/unsound practices (patronage politics)i think its kinda stupid to be arguing about whos right and whos wrong, whos more evil than who... it doesnt fucking matter cuz that shit alr happened and those people are alr dead HAJSHSJSHSJwhat matters is how it reflects the framework of philippine politics todayif youre mad about the things the *actually dead* characters of the film did *in the actual past*, which were not even sure are true (historical accuracy) or illegal, then you should direct that anger to the exact same shit but worse thats factually happening right now, thats actually illegal, and by people who are still alive and will continue to commit these crime unless theyre prosecuted and revolted againsti hope people know na this isnt just historical beef na they can just argue about forda drama and the marites-ing of it all and na its still happening right now and that were actual characters in the exact same story but worsethese arent just scenes and characters from a drama that you can just debate about for entertainment, because we live and experience these exact same real life scenes and characters in the everyday modern philippines. you shouldnt be rooting for aguinaldo or quezon or whoever character in that film; you should be rooting for yourself and the filipino people in the roles we play in philippine politics today and in our future as a nation

While Quezon definitely has less action compared to Heneral Luna and Goyo, the other films in the â€œBayaniverse,â€ I was not bored at all. The pacing might be gentler, but the storytelling and performances more than make up for it. The cast delivered strong portrayals that captured both the humanity and complexity of the historical figures, and the musical score complemented the drama beautifully. The production values were impressive as well. They may not be Hollywood-level in terms of scale, but they are undeniably Filipino in spirit and craftsmanship. You can really feel the trademark quality of TBA Studios throughout.As someone whoâ€™s a Filipino history nerd, I really appreciated how this film shed light on another side of Manuel L. Quezon, one thatâ€™s often overshadowed by his more famous political achievements. I also just learned that Quezon was a lawyer, and as a lawyer myself, it was fascinating to see how he was able to â€œplay the game,â€ navigating from being a trial lawyer to eventually becoming the President of the Philippines. It added another layer of depth and respect for his intellect and political skill.Having just been to Bataan last week for a historical and heritage trip, I felt an even deeper connection to the story and the period it depicted.I was also fortunate enough to have seen Quezonâ€™s Game a few years ago, and watching Quezon felt like seeing a grander, more expansive retelling of that same chapter in our history. The scope, emotion, and context were all heightened, giving a broader and richer perspective on Quezonâ€™s legacy.Overall, Quezon might not rely on action or spectacle, but it delivers a story that deepens our understanding of one of the key figures in our nationâ€™s history.

sinaunang yaoi is crazy bruh ğŸ˜­ğŸ™The first thing that really came to mind when I was watching this movie was the stylistic choice it decided to take on. The story-telling was incredible, following the movies made by Nadia with some scenes being her movie, while others being "real life". The way scenes were shot in "real life" in the style of a silent movie was genuinely so unique to me that it caught my eye. The merge of styles through out the entire movie all fit perfectly as well as contrasted each other well. Secondly, which is probably the most obvious, I enjoyed the perspective this movie gives towards not just Quezon but politics in general. I have heard the criticism about the fantasies this movie merges into what is the "truth", but I argue that is the point. The proper approach to movies like this is that after watching it, it should encourage you to research on your own. Be interested, be curious, and compare it to the life we live in. It brings Filipinos awareness back to the Philippines and our history. It may not all be true, but it sure is interesting. Of course, I have to mention the incredible acting of Jericho Rosales, Romnick Sarmenta, Mon Confiado, Therese Malvar, and the rest of the amazing cast. They brought these characters to life. There was a lot of debate about whether or not Jericho Rosales was the right fit for Quezon, but he did astoundingly well. I admire his efforts to be as true to life as he could be, accent and all. I am extremely attached to the style this movie had. Its use of colors, cinematography, and even sound were foundational to the narrative. The final scene, with quezon's quote of "I am the Filipino People, I am the Philippines!" brought chills all over my body. The envy in his voice when he questions why OsmeÃ±a was blessed with a healthy body and him not made me also question the irony of their story. It reminds me that sins are also reflected in the body. Wonderful movie, it brings about questions that we may never get answers to, and thoughts we may never complete. A beautiful and extravagantly painted picture of the past, that now leaves an impression on our present and the actions for our future.

The Questions of QuezonThroughout Jerold Tarog's trilogy, he raises important questions about heroism â€” and in Quezon (2025), he explores it not as an absolute truth but as a matter of perception. Sa dami ng na-trigger at nabuong kontrobersya, it begs the question: handa na nga ba tayo sa malayang diskusyon tungkol dito?â€œIndependencia!â€ The very ideal that Quezon and his forerunners fought and died for is finally within reach â€” pero paano ito aabutin ng bagong magiging presidente? The film thrives in the space between conflicting morals, fitting for a morally obsessed country riddled with corruption. Alin nga ba ang mas epektibo? Idealismo or realidad?The film is generous in portraying the old man's charm, eloquence, and impeccable sense of style. But in true Tarog fashion, he wasn't safe from being questioned either. Beneath the charisma lies his vanity, a leader fully aware of his strength and uses it to advance his ambitions -- whether for his country or for himself, who knows?Tarog's meta approach, blending fiction and history is a tricky but effective device. Nadia's films-within-the-film reveal two sides of the story, the same way Tarog does throughout his trilogy. The film doesnâ€™t just retell the past; it exposes how the narratives we accept as truth are constructed. Gaano nga ba kalaki ang papel ng media, pelikula, o ngayon, ng TikTok sa politika ng bansa?What remains unclear, however, is the role of the Americans in the narrative. I didnâ€™t quite appreciate how Governor Wood sort of became a "father figure" to the away-bati childishness of Quezon and OsmeÃ±a. Wasnâ€™t this separation engineered by the â€™Kano themselves?In today's battle against fake news, sensationalism and historical accuracy, Quezon's creative licenses may be a double-edged sword. But honestly? To hell with it!It's a triumph of Filipino filmmaking. It provokes, divides, and gets us all talking. Quezon doesnâ€™t claim to be the truth, but it forces us to question who gets to tell it. So really, what is there to lose?---------On a lighter note, as a tubong Quezon myself, I have to say â€” Echo nailed Quezonâ€™s American English accent of that time, but not quite his Tayabasing Tagalog.

Quezon provides an unbiased but contentious retelling of the titular characterâ€™s rise and fall in Philippine politics, his undeniable influence and charm, and his lasting impact in the countryâ€™s bid for independence.Despite the title, the film was not a glorification, but a critique on the character that is Manuel L. Quezon, the second president of the Philippines. Because while it was he who sought for Philippine independence, history tells us he might have done it in the not so cleanest of ways. While charming and influential, he was also brutal, unrelenting, and felt like he was Thanos or Darth Vader at times.The storytelling was great. Using film to backtrack the history of Quezon from his humble beginnings to his rise to presidency was really a good touch. It also really helped in presenting the exposition and Philippine history without it seeming like it was forced. It was like watching an educational film within a film.It was really paced well, too, as it divided chapters of Quezonâ€™s life based on his political enemies at the time â€“ it was like watching him go up the political ranks as he beat one adversary after another. Each scene felt intentional and it didnâ€™t feel like 2 hours have passed.Like any other historical account, this film took some big creative liberties as well. While it could be really good for dramatic effect and inducing a reaction, it could also spark controversy and be misconstrued as the truth. With this, I thought some of the choices couldâ€™ve stuck to the truth and just exaggerated them a bit.But all in all, Quezon is a great film for both the casual audience and history buffs. Itâ€™s a good critique on the character of Manuel Quezon and as well as on all the political figures surrounding him at the time. At the same time, itâ€™s also a good way to learn about the history of the Philippines, its political landscape, and its journey to independence. STAY FOR THE MID-CREDITS SCENE.

i really wanted to love this film, i was looking forward to it. i did enjoy watching it, both as a film and for its historical subject. the performances were really good, i can see that the actors really enjoyed playing their roles. the story was a bit meta as well which i liked.but the film had a lot going for it that really held it back. the production felt rushed. the actor for wood was wasted with so few scenes showing him. the story also spanned too wide a period, leaving no room for additional context as to what was happening in the film. i knew the historical context behind those scenes, but i doubt the same can be said of the general public.then there's the narrative itself. one issue that really bothers me with this trilogy is how they portray the americans as reasonable. that scene where wood was talking to some locals and how they exclaimed that independence was good enough to eat was icky. what exactly is that scene supposed to mean. it feels patronizing. and how they felt quezon even more so. that he was manipulative, shrewd, was already known. the director said he wanted to humanize him. but quezon had no redeeming qualities in the film. he had no arc. actually, if you look at all three movies, all the leading characters had no arcs. they lived and ended their films with nothing about them having changed, nor something interesting shown about them. luna was a hothead, goyo was a womanizer, and quezon was conniving. luna being this unwavering patriot didnt make sense to me. he ratted out on the katipunan at first, and only joined the revolution when it was finally against the americans. goyo felt too small a figure that even in his own film, the focus wasnt on him, it was on aguinaldo and mabini (granted, that the trilogy was more of aguinaldo's arc, than the figures important to his story). and quezon, for all his and his colleagues' shrewdness, won ph independence from a country so reluctant to recognize it. that it played into their ambition shouldnt faze us from recognizing the monumental task ahead of them. these figures are not beyond reproach, nor are the films wrong from portraying them the way they were portrayed. there are just elements in these films, that quezon really amplify, that prevent them from reaching their potential. these movies have moved the discourse, both in history and in film far, but could not any further.

A lot of drama involved and it makes me want to do my own research about this history.

Itâ€™s a masterfully crafted yet morally complex film that dares to strip a national hero of sanctity and reveal him as flawed, strategic, and deeply human. Visually stunning and bold in its storytelling, it reimagines Quezon not as a savior, but as the architect of the very system that made such saviors necessary. Jericho Rosales delivers a remarkable performanceâ€”his Quezon feels layered, seamlessly shifting from statesman to tactician with effortless charm. You can sense the performance behind the persona, the fragility behind the power.For me, Quezon isnâ€™t really a takedown of a hero; itâ€™s a mirror. It forces us to see how the leaders we admire, and even the systems we live in, are built by people as fragile and flawed as we are. And maybe thatâ€™s what makes it stingâ€”because it feels true.

Tarogâ€™s bayaniverse trilogy ends in a more implicating interpretation of a hero than his two previous films. There is no ambiguity in Quezonâ€™s machiavellian journey to power. Rosales treads close to a mere impersonation while Confiado shines through his restraint.Quezonâ€™s portrayal is flat compared to Lunaâ€™s and Goyoâ€™s because unlike the latter, the former is not portrayed as a human with flaws but simply a wretched opportunist fueled by greed and ego. Lunaâ€™s populist portrayal is balanced with his sincere desire to fight colonialism. Goyoâ€™s naÃ¯vetÃ© is tempered by his youthful idealism. Quezon, on the other hand, shows no redeeming factor. All in all, the conclusion to the trilogy reiterates that meeting your heroes is less glamorous than it seems.

The best film in the trilogy, both creatively and technically. It feels timely and deeply reflective of our current reality. The performances are compelling, and the film plays like a love letter to cinema, reminds me some moments akin to Citizen Kane and The Godfather Part II. Yet, its wide creative liberties blur the line between truth and fiction, inviting viewers to question and research what they have just seen. If this truly marks the end of the Bayaniverse, it stands as a powerful and fitting conclusion.

Though the movie paints an ugly picture of Quezon, I still see the humanity of a man that truly fought for the Philippines independence which is something we cannot deny. We also have accept that corruption, greed and deception is not new in filipino politics for it tells us that it began a long time ago but we have a lot of history of mistakes and failures to look back on to learn.

What a wonderfully nasty piece of work that portrays things in such a devilishly entertaining way. It was fun watching the politics in this movie portrayed in such a darkly comedic, performative, and theatrical way (especially the first half). The way everything seems so ultra rehearsed, the way they move, the way theyâ€™re blocked, etc. together with some lively camera work created for such a weirdly unserious yet engaging experience. Though its chronological sequencing was a bit confusing at the start, and itâ€™s pretty easy to get lost in what point of time weâ€™re in.Itâ€™s funny too because these people are determining the future and current state of the country, yet itâ€™s just a game to them; a stupidly intricate, dangerous game for power on who yaps and complains the loudest, all while Americans meddle with everything (as they always have), so it was over when Quezon stated that he learned from them.The biggest compliment Iâ€™d give is how this movie lowkey had some balls. I did NOT expect it to paint characters the way they did. They imply a shocking amount of things, and just straight up show how disgusting and slimy people were, albeit really smart and strategic for the worse.The foundation of this country, and its current systems have always been stained by foreigners (particularly the Americans), and it continues to be. Deny it all you want, the worst country in the world has that much power because it convinced the world that it does. The same way the loudest people always have, or end up, with some level of power.Thatâ€™s Philippine politics for yâ€™all; a loud, nasty, slimy game where the occupiers are always somehow the winners despite what people want to believe. Where the nastiest ones always somehow win, and itâ€™s because they know how to play this deranged, ugly game incredibly well.A game that sadly demands you surrender your morals for survival, and that survival turns into a disgusting lust for power. The worst guy you know won the game because the system favors them.Also, Ramon Magsaysay will appear in Avengers Doomsday ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚

Itâ€™s been a while since weâ€™ve seen a political film that brings us back to our senses and challenges what it means to be patriotic. (Maybe Gomburza tho) Quezon is a fresh film that introspects on the evils in both society and ourselves, and how we even play our role in corruption. I loved that Quezon is humanized as someone who had to play the game against bigger evils. Props to the super creative use of storytelling devices and other details, like Joven (journalist), newspapers, and films (all seemingly inspired from Citizen Kane). Much like Kane too, Quezonâ€™s character reveals itself and his ambitions piece by piece, shifting our perception of him until his death.The film does quite have a spoonfed narrative though. The script tends to overexplain its themes and motivations. Great that it makes everything more digestible to the general public, but it also takes away some subtlety.The cast is solid and GOATEDD, and special shoutout to DOP Pong Ignacio. Lighting and cameras were crazy. The production design also makes everything feels so real!! Excited for the next Bayaniverse

This film was indeed a pandora's box as how Mr. Avancena worded it. I came into the movie theater full of enthusiasm to watch it, but I came out full of questions, undecided if I was to believe the narrative, and unsatisfied. Upon going home, I had to research the next days about the veracity of this film. The film juxtaposed several elements of different timeframes such as colorized and non-colorized cinema to show the antagonist Quezon and the underdog Osmena narrative. It showed how Quezon tried to politick the Filipinos and Osmena (the Americans included)just to gain the seat for President. This also portrayed that patronage politics might have started in Quezon's time. However, just like the other Bayaniverse series, it is for the viewer to discern which part of the film was true or not because the disclaimer was only put in the beginning of the film. Thus, the viewers nee to read and research further. After watching the film, I also had the thought that publishing a book might not do so much after the trending phase of this film because in the era of social media, a book would not reach the same level of viewers that the film would reach especially if this will be released on online streaming platforms. On my part, it would be better if I would be able to read the researched part even on a blog online. The cast played well on their roles as Osmena, Quezon, and Aguinaldo. Other made up characters like Nadia and Joven, complemented the storyline . There was even a point where Nadia herself made fun of Quezon's traits. The main characters copied even the intonation of the politicians. Overall, it was a good film, but for a full length film, it feels incomplete. For a film just to end with "I am the Philippines", it feels unnatural. Well and good, Quezon died in America so there was really no good ending. But given that this was a mix of fiction and history, I hope they showed at least a memory of Quezon's memorial.

hindi na bago sa pilipinas ang konsepto ng isang â€œbayaniâ€ na magbibigay ng katarungan at pagbabago sa bansang sinilangan. hindi na bago ang pagbibitiw ng mga mahalimuyak na mga salita na may pagkukulang naman sa esensya, para lang linlangin ang taumbayan na sumapi at maniwala na may solusyon pa sa crisis na kanilang hinaharap. katulad nalang ng pagbibitiw ni quezon sa mga salitang â€œindependenciaâ€ at â€œdemokrasya,â€ na pinangako niyang maikakamit ng taumbayan kung makukuha niya ang kapangyarihan na kanyang inaasam. ngunit, hindi ang mga politikang ito ang magbibigay saâ€™tin ng tunay na independencia at demokrasyaâ€” tayo, bilang taumbayan, ang tunay na makakapagsulong ng karapatan natin sa demokrasyaâ€™t kasarinlan. hanggang ngayon, ramdam pa rin natin ang bakas ng imperyalismo sa bansa. ngunit, walang pagkakataon ang ordinaryong pilipino na pagtuunan ng pansin ang mga bagay na iyan dahil tayoâ€™y nakakulong sa isang sistemang neoliberalismo na hindi nanghihikayat ng malayang pagsasalita at pagpupuna sa mga taong nakaupo sa trono ng sakim at korap na kapangyarihan. power should always emanate from the people and not from the politicians who swore to serve us. even if these â€œgreatâ€ heroes have contributed to some important things in our country, we must always remember to never glorify them for simply doing their responsibilities. true heroism consists not in holding such power but in selflessly using it for the welfare of the people (rightfully so), and it is upon us to remind these â€œheroesâ€ that real greatness pertains to the Filipino people who continue to fight, hope, and demand a better nation. maybe when we get to that point, we will be able to comprehend the full realization of our democracy. on a more unserious note tho.. kudos to the production team for that bomb ass set design + score ğŸ™‚â€â†•ï¸ğŸ”¥ tba studios never fails grabe !!! i just know philippine cinema will reach greater heights in the next few years & iâ€™m also excited to be part of this field very soon !!! :~) mabuhay ang kasaysayan, ang mga artista ng bayan, at ang pelikulang pilipino <33

Watched for the historical aspect of the movie, stayed for the old man yaoi of Quezon and OsmeÃ±a.But on a serious note, this movie is a different tone from Heneral Luna and Goyo. The cinematography, soundtrack, and way of storytelling is a shift from the first two movies thus giving the viewers the feeling of entering and being in a new era of the Philippines. It's purely the political aspect, the way campaigns are nowadays in the Philippines could be traced back to Quezon.Additionally, this movie is a question of hermenuetics - which interpretation of history do you find true? I could see why the movie is controversial, however, the interpretation is valid. It is just a matter of which one do you find truthful - Quezon as a hero of the Filipino people or a man hungry for power.

Si Casey ang reyna ng Quezon City

I am leaving here my thoughts I made on my notepad, if it seems very essay-ish and inaccurate I am sorry I tried my best to write my thoughts 4 hours after watching the film. Here it is:â€œHindi ka hari!â€â€œSigurado ka?â€In this film we unravel the first President of the Philippines in a time where we never really knew what independence or being free meant. It was just simply a glittery word we acquainted with being free from Americans and establishing our own rule.As far as I am aware 1935 was an establishment of a commonwealth to transition to 1946 which was our genuine independence as a nation. We see this film through a sort of journalistic storytelling lenses of Joven Hernando (a fictional character), as he threads through what he went through prior to this film and the aftermath of Goyo towards the time he was reporting Quezonâ€™s senatorial endeavors, his run for presidency, and unspooling the threads of who and what Quezon is. What is Politics? What is Patronage Politics?Politics has roots in Aristotleâ€™s work, Politika, a Greek word which consequently means things concerning the polis (city). It is the ability by which one can use power, or direct influences to an individual, group, community, or a nation that a person â€œdoing politicsâ€ busy themselves with. This occurs at all levels of a society.Now what is patronage politics? Associations, positions, promotions, and contracts are based on personal connections and friendships rather than pure merit. This is also what we call the padrino system or clientelism. Why am I highlighting this? You may think of our so called Bayanis as the glorified images they were portrayed as and made up to be by textbooks, anecdotes, and so on. But, they are just as horrid and grotesque as any 21st century politician can be. As Quezon believed it, it was a game, and the trick was to cheat it. Noble LiesIn the movie we see Joven and Quezon have a short argument about truth, their difference, and why it matters when theyâ€™ve attained a victory for independence or freedom. They reference many classic texts and philosophical concepts from which Quezon mentioned â€œmentira nobleâ€, Spanish for a noble lie.This is a concept derived from Platoâ€™s â€˜The Republicâ€™ in which Plato discusses that societies are built on such lies. If the masses believe in something (independence), then there is something to fight for. (Krause, 2019) Which in the film he utilizes as a way to earn power and along the way do some good for those who have placed his trust on him.Jovenâ€™s dialogue and realizations in contrast to this throughout the film reflects the audienceâ€™s gradual disposition over what can we believe from Quezon or in contemporary times, those who claim to have the nationâ€™s best interests.Are Filipinos that fucking stupid?The humor in the film is great. Satire doesnâ€™t necessarily mean a quality of being funny but just the moments that are spread sporadically throughout the film makes you smile and chuckle while also grappling with how twisted the butt of the jokes are. There is this moment when Leonard Wood who went on a trip around the Philippines to survey whether the Filipinos were truly capable of independence asked a few townspeople along with his translator if they knew what independence meant, to which one replied that: â€œThey become full (their stomach) from the thought of it,â€ I couldnâ€™t help but laugh and overhear a chuckle from 1 other watcher besides me. (Albeit what I quoted is not direct as I am struggling remembering the exact line. )So the question is are Filipinos stupid? No. We believe the propagandas, the persuasive anecdotes, what others say, and what we say because we hope for nothing but the best for all of us. It is not our fault that those we place our trust in chooses to betray usâ€”the same way Quezon did to Joven, the same way Quezon did to Aguinaldo, and the same way Aguinaldo did to Luna and Bonifacio. I cannot stress how weâ€™re stuck in this perpetual loop and how deep-rooted such issue is. Alas, human nature and greed is a mystical thing, it surpasses all reasoning and thought.But, in this day and age, if you cannot use history and the information at your disposal to think rationallyâ€”you are a stupid Filipino. Sorry.The WomenWhat is Aurora Quezon, Maria Agoncillo, and Carmen and Nadia Hernandoâ€™s role in all of this? Well, to show the intricacies and persistence of women who stand at the shadows of history. Aurora Quezon, behind the scenes is a woman who could stand her ground at the same level as Manuel Quezon.Maria Agoncillo, becomes Aguinaldoâ€™s anchor as he goes through the loss and dirty tactics done by Quezon. Carmen and Nadia are smart women whose integrity and careers are supported by their husband in a time where women were otherwise discouraged. An article by the Lifestyle Inquirer goes into interviews with the respective actresses and provides valuable insight for these characters and how important they are. You can search for it. With that, I hope to soon see a movie about a female hero, as the director also hopes to do if given the chance.Quezon has a husband, OsmenaThey should get married, honestly. They bicker and make up like a husband and his wife would. The parallels run deep, friend or foe, tampuhan, the ancient and homosexual version of Bongbong and Sara. You will understand what I mean when you see the film, it sounds diabolical, I know.Their dynamic is like two academic rivals who do nothing but outdo each other and try to tolerate each other and when hurt make up for it. For instance, the Hare-Hawes-Cutting Act and the blatant copying of assignment but slightly changing the wording with the consequent Tydings-McDuffie Act all because Quezon wanted the credit when Hare-Hawes-Cutting was his idea. Finallyâ€¦â€œMaybe itâ€™s about proving what you can do, instead of proving what is right.â€ â€” Carmen HernandoSheâ€™s right, at the end of the day why should these politicians never fulfill and serve their own interests? At this point it is an interplay of psychological warfare, scheming, power play, and gaining something out of their endeavors whether it be favors, money, or something to leverage themselves further. But how will we, as a country move on forward with confidence and trust towards those who govern us when betrayal is in the table? When the nationâ€™s interests arenâ€™t fulfilled? When they are the sole reason we canâ€™t get ourselves out of this damning rut? Perhaps this 21st century we ask, if there is a 22nd century will the Filipinos then, be able to live a better life? Because I have seen enough to say that in my lifetime at least, itâ€™s never going to get any better.Suffice to say, I loved this film. I availed of the â‚± 250.00 discount allowed for students and teachers, and I did not feel like I wasted money at all. If we talk about the technical aspects like: the direction, music, composition, casting, and wardrobe, they were all perfect. Youâ€™ll never think throughout watching that they chickened out with giving Quezon (2025) huge production value. In a time where corruption is rampant in Philippine politics, well in retrospect it has always been, this film could not be any more relevant and timely. I implore everyone to support Filipino film and cinema, as they are a treasure trove of bright and brimming ideas awaiting audiences to see them.

A fitting conclusion to Tarog's trilogy attempting to define the Filipino hero: Quezon combines the heat of Heneral Luna and the introspection of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral. The film holds firm to the trilogy's assertion that our national heroes are not without fault, and that, perhaps, we regained our independence partly because of those faults. Manuel Quezonâ€”like Luna and Del Pilarâ€”feels flesh and blood here, capable of both heroism and monstrosities.

Jerrold Tarog closes his Bayaniverse trilogy with Quezon, a sharp, ambitious political drama that trades the gunfire of Heneral Luna and Goyo for quieter battles fought through charm, rhetoric, and image.Jericho Rosales completely disappears into the role, giving a performance thatâ€™s both commanding and unsettling. He plays Quezon not as a spotless hero but as a man who understands how leadership relies on performance. The film doesnâ€™t glorify him; it examines him. It shows how charisma can inspire and manipulate at the same time, and how power often hides behind elegance.The movie looks beautiful, with careful production design, steady pacing, and clean editing that keeps even long political exchanges engaging. Tarogâ€™s direction is thoughtful and confident, peeling back Quezonâ€™s myth not to tear it down but to reveal the man underneath thatâ€™s ambitious, flawed, and burdened by what it takes to lead.Seen at SM City DasmariÃ±as

I believe in the artistic direction of the crew behind Quezon. Tarogâ€™s willingness to treat a towering historical figure such as Manuel L. Quezon not as a flawless hero, but as a complex, ambitious individual, gives the film a bracingly fresh tone. The production design, pacing and cinematography all feel meticulously crafted, itâ€™s clear the team sought to challenge the idea of grand national myth and instead expose the power-games behind it. In doing so, Quezon invites us to see how legacy is manufactured, and how leadership is as much performance as service. I found the portrayal compelling and the moral ambiguity rich, making the film more than just a biopic. It becomes a meditation on nationhood, ambition and compromise.

While considered polarizing, I still do appreciate the storytelling. I have a lot of thoughts on this as well as it's parallels to the "Hamilton" Broadway Musical, but I shan't divulge further. The only thing I would change about this is the use of the silent film aesthetic. At first, I liked it because it brought something new to the table and did tie well to the artistic intent to the film but as it went on, I felt like it somehow lost the plot. I felt like it didn't capture well which parts were reflective of the "film" and which ones were the supposed "actual" occurences. It was only at the end where I felt it become harmonious with the other two films in the series because of the familiar feeling it invoked. Maybe what I really wanted to get from the film was to viscerally understand the history it focuses on. How does it's overall storytelling differ from how I would read it from a textbook? How will an unbiased journalist portray it without being propaganda-like?Nonetheless, I loved the movie! If it gets me raving or wanting to disect each artistic choice made for it, then it's a good film. Jerrold Tarog never disappoints!

The movie immediately brought to mind the political intrigue of the Netflix series House of Cards, but infused with the signature Tarog humor and quips. This is consistent with the entire "Bayaniverse" Trilogy.The deconstruction of our national heroes and figures is a perfect use of cinema in retelling history. By humanizing them into characters with their own beliefs, goals, egos, and flaws, the film makes them relatable. While creative and fictional liberties were certainly taken, the general gist, and hopefully the core message of the story will be received and resonate well with the audience.Also, on a final note: what the hell, Magsaysay next?

Me and my friends were like seven minutes late to the cinema because of the ticket line which was. Devastating. I missed the first few scenes, which I think included JC Santos, and that just ruined the experience for me a little. You have no idea how sad that makes me. I kept thinking about it the whole time. Anyway. I really love the cinematography, the music, the production design, the pacing, everything. This movie felt so beautiful and put together. The colors and composition reminded me of Wes Anderson in a way and that was such a joy to look at. I always love a good non-linear story so that was extra fun to watch too, though I didnâ€™t fully get it at first because I didnâ€™t get to see the first few scenes. >:(Iâ€™ve always loved how Tarog uses Joven to tell the story so now, the use of Jovenâ€™s daughterâ€™s film as a storytelling device really got me. The documentary (??) bits were one of my favorite parts. So Charlie Chaplin. I really loved that. The script was also really well written and the way the actors delivered them was so on-point. Most of them are some of my favorite actors too. Rusca got recast which made me sad for a minute because he was my favorite in Heneral Luna, but then I found out the old actor was actually a horrible person, so um. Sucks.The yaoification of Quezon and OsmeÃ±a is... interesting. They always find a way to make these movies seem a bit gay. Interesting. So. I think this movie is way better than Goyo because that one honestly bored me (I know the quiet aesthetic was intentional but I didn't like it okay). But Heneral Luna is still my favorite. Lunaâ€™s story just hits harder. But yh, this one still feels stronger in terms of the technical stuff. It's very neat and I can't wait to rewatch it. I think this would be 10x better after the 2nd watch.I donâ€™t know much about history, so I really enjoy watching movies like this. So much stuff to learn. Still..... #BringBackJovente

â€‹"Bakit siya ang pinagpala ng mabuting kalagayan? Hindi ba nila kilala kung sino ako? I am Manuel Luis Quezon! I am the Filipino People! I am the Philippines!"â€‹The final lines of the film perfectly encapsulate the kind of person Manuel Luis Quezon wasâ€”a power-hungry, manipulative, all-knowing, chameleon king.â€‹Tarog's portrayal of Quezon displayed him as a human being; a being with his own selfish greeds and desires. Books and documentaries would often portray Quezon as nothing but a "perfect president," so shedding light on him as a trapo will definitely have his relatives shaking their heads at the representation.â€‹Heroes were often depicted as nothing but thatâ€”perfect, heroic, symbols of peace and protection. However, in Tarog's final installment of the Bayaniverse Trilogy, he portrayed Quezon under a different lens: he was portrayed as imperfect, flawed. Quezon was sick, twisted, and outwardly selfishâ€”something that made him stand out from Goyo and Luna. (Btw, my memory could be serving me wrong.) Goyo and Luna were portrayed as these "sacrificial" heroes whose actions were driven by their patriotism and love for the country. Quezon, however, was not. His actions were driven by his need to have and stay in power. As mentioned, "Mauuna pang pumuti ang uwak kaysa mawalan ka ng kapangyarihan, Quezon" for he did anything and everything in his power to ensure that he was never in a position of no power.â€‹Quezon was terrifying for how "real" he is in this day and time. He was able to manipulate the people by abusing the Filipino's belief of utang na loobâ€”and he used that as ammunition in every political war, which ultimately led to his victory. Another factor was how Quezon curated his image of "perfection" by utilizing his connections to the fullestâ€”even going as far as trampling over the livelihood and well-being of the people if it meant staying in power. He used people at his disposal, all the while maintaining a picture-perfect image to the media and the people.â€‹Quezon is terrifying because while he may not have been fighting armies on the war zones, he was pulling the strings from the best seat in the house.

Watched Heneral Luna one time ago and never seen Goyo (but willing to watch after). Quezon is the final film from TBA's Bayniverse. It honestly feels like a satisfying conclusion to its said trilogy. I was never known to be interested in early Philippine history. I watched this because it's a film that's highly anticipated nationwide. I was really impressed by how the film goes from Manuel's early life through films, and how his life is in turmoil through the battle for independence. However, the film explores his desire for deception to gain much power to become the second president of the Philippines. Something so sinister that I understand that's how Jerrold interpreted it based on facts about Quezon's "game".Every aspect in every scene resembles the reality we still have. We're still in a developed country, which is not surprising to say the least. We're humans playing by the rules and laws. But for our country, it's what we live for.I adored how the film opens, but then I get a bit overwhelmed afterward. Thankfully, I was able to connect the dots on what's happening. I was blown away by the visuals, production set, and its ensemble cast of this film. It's truly amazing to see those in a Philippine film. Although, the sound mixing and camera work felt they needed to fill up on some scenes. Almost to make this film perfect.Now, the film Quezon became a national debate, thanks to one of Quezon's descendants at the Q&A post-screening. He stated that the film affected him, claiming it's a satire rather than a biopic. And he's not the only one; a few of Quezon's families are also affected by the film afterward. Many hated, many defend. It is very common to see this happening in every biopic film ever made. Filmmakers create a film based on a real-life figure, followed by credible sources available. Despite that, you will never escape from any person who knows a real-life figure because they don't provide you with any consideration before the film was made. To respond to that fiasco, I dare to say that this film is worth watching for everybody who's not interested in or complains about it. The disclaimer says it all, and yet they roared for a boycott. But as long as Quezon tells you exactly what the director and writers had envisioned, the film is the representation of our struggle to handle our country due to lies and deception.

"Being a hero, it's all about perception." It feels surreal that I was watching Quezon for the second time while, at the same moment, around 800 kilometers away from Cebu, one of Quezonâ€™s grandsons was throwing a fit toward the cast and crew for what he felt was a disrespectful portrayal of his grandfather. Itâ€™s expected that his descendants would have mixed-to-negative feelings about this film, so I get where theyâ€™re coming from. I think what held me back fromâ€¦

â€œHow can you be a guardian of truth if you can only see one side?â€what a way to end the Bayaniverse trilogy with a banger ender: being a hero is all about perception. three movies later, i hope it gets to be an exercise for everyone to critically think about how we view the heroes we look up to and see them in a new lightâ€”stripped of all their laurels, flawed and utterly humanized; not because we want to taint their names and contributions, but because it opens our eyes to blind fanaticism. to paraphrase Maria Ressa, it is only by knowing and having these facts will we have truth; truth that will build trust; all of which in pursuit of building a shared reality and thus democracy that will champion the countryâ€™s independence. but until this government is infested by politicians instead of public servants, and until this country forgets to study and learn from its past, one shouldnâ€™t be surprised to see this country still run like hell. p.s. the emotions in that speech scene towards the end got me teary eyed!
