Just watched Quezon. I want to start by saying I think Filipino films are not quite my jam, unfortunately.I wanted to like this. It had its moments, and I get the idea it wanted to convey.Quezon is a depiction of how Americans influenced Philippine politics into what it is todayâ€”for better or worse (mostly worse). It was not a good painting of Manuel Quezon by any means.I grew up not really minding Philippine presidents. Quezon, for me, felt like a decent person, someone who was deeply connected with the USâ€”President of the Commonwealth. The film depicted him as a sneaky politician who would do everything to stay in power. He was charismatic and had a way with his words and aura. Unfortunately, the whole time I felt like I missed much more nuance in him. I felt his characterization was too one-sided; it seemed like he was used as a plot point to get a point across. The film was actually confusing to follow at first due to the differing timelines.The problem with political films is that they tend to be biased from a certain point of view. This felt like one of those films. I wished I had seen a complex characterâ€”one who is a lion when he needs to be but perhaps also a person who genuinely believed in something.This was my first entry in the 'bayaniverse' by Tarog. Perhaps most of what was depicted was true, but I think it left out some of the important parts of what made Quezon a fascinating Filipino president.I did like the heart of what it wanted to depict. We live in a political regime where corporations are the boss and the leaders do things to stay in powerâ€”not for the people.The acting was not that good. They hired a 'for the money' American actor, and the leads did not feel authentically Filipino. Or maybe the writing was just mid.
There's a sense of liberation in seeing heroes being portrayed in an unflattering light. It does not make them dislikeable per se, it makes them human, pulling them back to their core essence.

If I'm being completely honest, my first few days back in Manila's included a lot of conversations centred around the gross ineptitude of the country's government leaders. So I guess it's kind of fitting that Quezon's the first film I got to see in the cinema with my parents and my sister since, like, forever. And I can't 100% speak to the factual accuracy in this picture (which makes sense because, at the end of the day, this is still just a movie). But I am glad that it's sparked even more conversations between my family and I about figures and events in Philippine history that are basically repeating themselves in the present. Also, it helps to have a huge movie star attached to an otherwise flawed but still pretty entertaining story at the heart of Jerrold Tarog's latest addition to the Bayani-verse. Definitely recommend that more people watch Quezon, double check the data, and talk about the stuff they know (or think they know) because it's certainly got a lot of interesting ideas that are worthy of extended thought or discussion.

I am the Philippines The third installment of Tarrogs' Bayaniverse explores on Manuel L Quezon as a four part film; The Hero, The Great Political Player, and the lobbyists towards the Philippines' Independence.Unlike the first two films which focus on the fight for a Revolutionary Government, Quezon, sets up a new story toward nation building translated to themes of power and play in the political arena(of which parallels to the existing political patterns of Philippine Politics). The good points of the film would be the idea of a film within a film; how media was an excellent medium to portray the two sides of Quezon as the Hero and the Trapo(traditional politician). Jericho Rosales did and excellent execution portraying someone who despite being narcissistic and intelligent gentleman you can't help but to love the guy.Another good point was the role Joven Hernando as the main protagonist guised as a side character which has been consistent on all three films. The role of Joven, a fictional character meant to symbolize the viewers but my interpretation would also be the youth who are seeking for truth. Joven meaning youth in Spanish is an excellent name for the character inviting the youth to critically think and discern for a more Independent Philippines.This last installment,while it stirs controversy on the portrayal of President Manuel L.Quezon, opens a fresh perspective how we can further improve our flawed system To quote the late President MLQ"I would rather have a government run like hell by Filipinos,than run like heaven by Americans, because no matter how bad a Filipino Government might be, we can always change it"

i believe this a good conclusion in bayaniverse. the movie keeps me questioning, how do we even define bayani? what concept do we make a stand point to have a bayani? well, yes totoo it's a perception. kasi we see our heroes in 'perfect' and full of glossified praises, but in reality (which is hard to swallow) they are humans that has flaws. Now it makes sense why the other movie has Quezon's Game. Basically and literally MLQ knows how to play his A-game. Madumi ang sistema ng politika. Kung gusto mo ng kapangyarihan, alyansa, at lakas â€” rurumihan mo at gagawa ka ng pangalan dahil nga ang sistema ng politiko sa ating bansa ay naghahangad tayo na mga leader na may 'messianic' dahil tayo ay lugmok sa mapang-alipustang sistema. Quezon's took that mindset kaya mabilis siya nakahanap ng propaganda. And during that time, iyon ang isinisigaw ng tao, kaya he took that chance to make name out of it and gain the power he has.This is also a good storytelling of how 'populism' is existing in our country. Politicians do not care majority for our well-being as a nation. As long as they get benefit out of it, they will seize the opportunity to create name para makatakbo sa mga mataaas na posisyon. + plus Joven Hernando's character is powerful and its rich. Ang metaphor lang sakin journalista siya, and basically i love how he represents all of us. Tayo ang mga mata at nakakakita sa realidas ng ating lipunan

Story Beats and writing was very good at keeping the attention of the audience from the time jumps to the volley between flashbacks and fast forwards. Production design could have been improved but was made up for by the stellar performances of the cast and ensemble, Capturing the nuances of our history book photos come to life. The character study done here (especially) by the lead was very spot on. Although wrapped in discourse and controversy I think the movie has done its job by pushing people to dig deeper and find out more about the historical figures we either praise or persecute. in the words of quezon "perception is everything".

I know my fair share of Philippine history, but every time I watch a film about anything related to it, my knowledge expands and I get to explore new perspectives. To be honest, Manuel L. Quezon was the president that I never really got to learn deeply about, hence the reason why I watched this film. It was an eye opener. The film was divided into different sections, each about someone Quezon was associated with, making me able to understand all point of views.

More than the moral dilemma of campaigns, Quezon was a deconstruction of our loyalists culture towards political actors, diverting us from their humane and flawed tendencies . And although it synthesizes fiction in narrating a political legacy, it continues to be a reflection of how the public has its influence on the politics we have today because of our blinded perception of the people we should only consider as public servants and not heroes.

Interesting, Insightful, and Innovative look at the rise of Former Philippine President Manuel L. Quezon (b. 1878 - d. 1944). Being an American Foreign-National (though coming from Philippine parentage) residing in the Philippines, I was amazed to have realized that I came into the movie with more than a rudimentary knowledge of modern Philippine History. This movie excelled in portraying President Quezon in a very "larger-than-life" person (who historically was very much so). Yet, at the same time, the movie seems to convey the impression that many artistic liberties were taken to make the movie more entertaining rather than to be a more historic portrayal of the real Quezon. Notwithstanding, the movie does not shy away from asking ground-breaking questions such as "How far will one go to ensure the independence of a nation?"

There are different entry points on how to read Quezon. Perhaps the most urgent for me to look at, is its distribution and promotion â€” how its coining of "Bayaniverse" has transmuted to multiple efforts of sustaining its captured audience from Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018). In these ongoing attempts of serving its captured audience, Quezon has both failed and served them at best. By constantly challenging and deconstructing our ideals of heroism, Quezon has to eventually hurt the Pinoy pride, which I personally found an achievement. Sometimes, to offend the audience is to serve them best. By structuring a film (or films) within the film, Quezon mirrors what many of us refuse to see and can't yet actively confront, that our eventual participation in the culture of patronage politics has built the Duterte - Marcosverse.Meanwhile, I couldn't help but realize that Goyo is actually my favorite of the 3. It renders a cinematic language mostly spoken in a spiritual context: deep diving in introspection of our personal and collective complexities.

an interesting film that doesnâ€™t glorify a hero but instead reveals the ultimate truth, the other side of the coin. weâ€™ve all read about quezonâ€™s achievements and contributions to the philippines, as textbooks often portray him as an untouchable figure. but are we ready to see the other side of his story?iâ€™ve always loved history since elementary school. it was one of my favorite subjects because it was easy for me to memorize important details. but thatâ€™s also the problem. we were taught to memorize history, not to understand it. we remember the names, dates, and events, but we rarely think critically about what they actually mean.thatâ€™s why this movie was so refreshing to watch. it connected all those historical terms and lessons i used to memorize, making them finally make sense in context. itâ€™s no longer just information i learned to pass an exam, but a deeper understanding of the story behind it all.itâ€™s sad to think that our government hasnâ€™t changed even a bit from before until now. the same dirty political tactics, corruption, maneuvering, and patronage politics still exist today. itâ€™s truly disappointing that the philippines hasnâ€™t progressed at all under this kind of politics. i just hope that in the near future, our country will no longer be filled with politicians, but with genuine public servants who truly care for the people.

Jerrold Tarogâ€™s Quezon is, quite frankly, a bold attempt to deconstruct a â€œnational heroâ€ long revered through the sanitized lens of our school textbooks. I appreciate its almost relentless flow of exposition, which, despite its weight, is presented with precision and clarity rather than coming off as tacky. Jericho Rosalesâ€™s portrayal of Manuel Quezon is, for the most part, spot-on and convincingly deliveredâ€”he truly understood the assignment. Moreover, regardless of any controversy the film may have sparked upon release (such as outrage among Quezonâ€™s direct descendants), Tarogâ€™s vision remains clear: to reveal what politicians are truly made of, how their facades unravel when stripped bare, and how they continue to pass down the same traits to future generations.

No wonder Quezon's grandson's nepo baby ass was so angry (kinda funny, though). Needless to say, the film highlights how crucial for us Filipinos to critically examine our leaders, their use of power, and political ambitions, especially during these trying times in our politics.

Obviously this film says a lot about how politicians operate in the Philippines, something that I had very little insight of until recently. It neither condemns nor glorify Quezon. You get to ask yourself if the risks and compromises were worth it. As you see how the man slowly corrodes his ideals because he plays the game too well. I hope that when the time comes for me to vote in any upcoming election, I can see the game being played in front of my eyes.Also, when the Ramon Magsaysay post-credit scene dropped I shed multiple tears.

I appreciate how this film challenges the notion of being a â€œBayaniâ€ differently compared to Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018).The film isnâ€™t afraid to show that Manuel L. Quezon was a deeply flawed and problematic person despite all his achievements and contributions in helping the Philippines understand and reach independencia.(Random funny side note: It tickles my brain every time they say â€œindependencia,â€ and when they curse in Filipino with their thick accents.)Itâ€™s necessary to have narratives like this every once in a while because people tend to put others on pedestals and perceive them as flawless and ideal individuals. This is dangerous because idolatry leads to leniency, leniency leads to conformity, and conformity leads to collapse.Everything breaks down when we put the weight and responsibility of an entire country on one person alone, instead of recognizing that it also takes an entire nationâ€™s worth of people to create change.This story is socially relevant not only because of our current political landscape here in the Philippines, but also as a reminder of the importance of looking back on our history to ensure we never repeat the mistakes of the past.The film is also masterfully crafted on a technical level and is arguably the best in the Bayaniverse so far. The direction, cinematography, editing, staging, musical score, and performances from the entire cast. They all shine here. Every single department that worked on this film fired on all cylinders, and it shows.There is also a level of playfulness present here (Mostly because of the score, staging, and performances) in the film that I really appreciate. Itâ€™s like a new flavor being introduced for the Bayaniverse and I welcome it very much.It was exceptionally made and definitely one of my favorite films of 2025. I hope to see more films like this from TBA Studios.Better stay for that mid-credits tease!

two words: revolutionary cinema. quezon, amidst multiple opinions stirred due to its ability to challenge main character norms of being picture-perfect or blatantly evil, has set the standard for philippine cinema to begin questioning the authenticity of our history and our roots. it obviously did a great job in personifying such a glorified figure like manuel quezon, who used to be seen as a national hero, but upon exiting the cinemas, its really got you asking what is real or not. is he really worth the praise heâ€™s been receiving from the filipino nation?other than that, they successfully portrayed the flaws and beauty of philippine politics; how ugly it can get, and how it has always been up to the nationâ€™s voices to determine whether or not they want to receive the treatment they deserve or not. it mirrors current reality without being too complex to understand, it embodies the philippines as a whole, kumbaga perfect fit talaga ang tagline ni quezon na â€œI am the Philippines.â€jericho rosales was stellar, karylle was empathic, mon confiado was agitatingly pitiful, and jerrold tarog was superb. you can see the consistency of the arts in his craft, encapsulating every detail of quezonâ€™s life into his bayaniverse vision that translates beautifully into the soul of philippine cinema. walang patumpik-tumpik in all movies of the bayaniverse, hence, the emergence of what i call revolutionary cinema. more films like this please! and more movie goers to encourage fellow filipinos to come see them. letâ€™s utilize our homegrown talents to possibly bring upon the change our country needs.

Of all the Bayaniverse movies, Quezon (2025) is arguably the most polarizing. I'll try my best to condense my thoughts, organizing them based on meta analysis, historical truth, and social commentary.In its most meta, Quezon (2025) stands to subvert audience expectations with its characterization of Manuel L. Quezon. In Tarog's previous films, he sought to shed a more sympathetic light on misunderstood figures of Philippine history. Portraying Luna as a passionate and enlightened man, Goyo as misguided and young, and even Aguinaldo as complex and misunderstood. However, how could he showcase the story of a man who's well-beloved by a nation? It's in the best interest of many to concede that although polarizing, Quezon being characterized as the progenitor of patronage politics is on brand for Dir. Tarog. Luna and Goyo were already established by key aspects of their stories, either by being hot-headed or accomplished and young. Jerrold Tarog's brand has been to take what the audience may know and provide a different perspective, thus explaining Quezon's diva tantrums and arrogance. However, the question remainsâ€”Is it historically accurate? From my understanding of the film, Tarog already sought to answer those questions within the film itself. Accuracy and truth is greatly influenced by the filmmaker, her patron, and even preexistent ideas of who a person is. History is not my career, thus I can't provide a professional opinion on its accuracy. What I can say, however, is that if Tarog's own opus is be trustedâ€”he, the director, is merely a man. He is not infallible and thus, the truth as he knows it, may not entirely be what it is. Historical accuracy cannot simply be based on its costuming and subtle details in props, but also the integrity of the story itself. Lastly, the movie is obviously a very nail-on-the-head commentary on politicians whose personal ambitions are hid thinly behind a persona of nationalism. It feels like a jab against growing populist sentiments, but antagonizes the greedy who sought to reap its benefits with little sincerity. It explores how the formula for gaining power as an ambitious, dynastic politician has never really changed in the past century or so. Unless the people themselves are willing to start questioning the integrity of the people they sought to empower with their votes, for every disgraced politician another corrupt politician will take his place. Perhaps I'm reading too much into this, but Quezon (2025) feels like some sort of cinematic social experiment that Jerrold Tarog gave us. He's seen the power of Heneral Luna and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, perhaps this is just him leaving a movie that's on-purposely polarizing so that the people can be forced to think about the credibility of everything they see. Even if not his intention, it's great to see this play out.The movie was enjoyable and the stylistic difference definitely ties into how we're in a brand new era of Philippine history. I'm hoping to see a similar thing be done with any of his future works âœ¨

I'll be honest, I didn't know much about Manuel Quezon outside the fact that he's considered a national heroâ€”and a bit about the questionable land acquisition practices in the establishment of his namesake city.And not being a huge fan of biopics, I was just hoping for a nuanced look at a national hero.But holy shit, this pulled no punches. Quezon is portrayed to have learned the worst of the political game from the Americans. Effective? Incredibly so. Honorable? Nope.I had to pull up some recordings of him afterwards, Rosales absolutely nailed his cadence. The acting here was incredible. The cinematography some of the best I've seen from a Filipino movie. And best of all, it LOOKED like a movie. This was cinematic.And surprising for a political biopic, this was a blast. It was hilarious. It didn't take itself too seriously (or seriously at all, really).Maybe those more familiar with the story will be annoyed by the heavy use of exposition, but I found it to be helpful. I'm not here to shit on anyone else's national heroesâ€”I've got plenty of American historical figures I can do that to. But, this does do a great job of depicting how Quezon's style of politicking, and selling off his country's resources to the highest bidders, seems to have led to the rampant levels of corruption seen today, 100 years later.Added to My Filipino Film Diary

A scathing and surprisingly humorous indictment of Quezon and his supposedly scummy character, so much so that it enters caricature territory, but I'm reminded of Tarrog's overarching project of interrogating what a bayani means. This is supported further by the dimension that the film adds to Aguinaldo who was a clear villain in "Heneral Luna." There's a dearth of (good) films about history and politics in mainstream contemporary Filipino film, so I was pleased to see some unconventional editing and cinematographic choices here that are more common in foreign biopics. The incorporation of the silent film was a clever device all around â€“ a way to deepen the fictional Joven's story while beefing up the commentary on media as a tool of propaganda, a cost-cutting yet effective touch on the artificiality of celebrity politics, a self-aware reflection on how history is written by the victors. Rosales' transformation is a thrill to watch and a testament to the ripening of his craft but I was also really captivated by Sarmienta's performance. Sometimes the script sounds like it's lifted from a HEKASI textbook but it's forgivable for people like me who need the refresher course.

With memorable performances from the cast, compelling storytelling, and masterful direction, Quezon (2025) deserves to stand and be praised on its own. Still itâ€™s best viewed as the final installment to the Bayaniverse trilogy. In this lens, we really see Jerrold Tarogâ€™s thesis throughout the series: â€œAng pagkabayani, itâ€™s all about perception.â€Heneral Luna (2015) showed a hero with unrivaled passion and patriotism. John Arcillaâ€™s Luna is a hero people wanted to rally behind and emulate. He was branded as a leader who could have saved the Philippines, if not for the infighting between the revolutionaries. Yes, he was a flawed character, but you wanted to root for him. Never mind that he never won a battle â€“ his profound love of country made up for it. The timing of the film also couldnâ€™t be more perfect â€” it was released during an intense rise in populism. The film arguably contributed to Rodrigo Duterte winning the 2016 presidential elections, but thatâ€™s another story.Goyo: The Boy General (2018) was more subdued. There was no way to replicate Lunaâ€™s fiery personality and Arcillaâ€™s performance as a cussing, temperamental general, so it was only natural to take another approach. Paulo Avelino gave life to the young, inexperienced boy general. In history classes, Goyo was often described as a martyr who died for his beloved country. The film portrayed his conflict â€“ was he really loyal to his country or only to Aguinaldo? Was his sacrifice heroism or blind servitude?Quezon depicted a trapoâ€™s rise to power. Jericho Rosalesâ€™ Quezon showed ability to pull all the tricks in the book: propaganda, lying, self-serving alliances, politicking, patronage politics. He wasnâ€™t the first to do them (and we know from our daily experiences now that heâ€™s not the last), but he no doubt mastered them. Describing him as a chameleon was an understatement. Always performing and projecting what the other side wants him to be.More importantly, Quezon brought the trilogyâ€™s thesis full circle. The film, like the two before it, argues that heroism is not black and white. â€œAng pagkabayani, itâ€™s all about perception.â€The film within a film device effectively blurred the lines between reality and fiction. The switching between different Quezons (the old version, the young version, the fictionalized young version), the nonlinear storytelling and changing perspectives, further served to confuse the audience about objective history and revisionist recollection.But the filmâ€™s biggest and most-rewarding bet is making Joven Hernando (the audience surrogate) an active participant to the story. By showing that he can be swayed by narratives, blinded by his own biases, be bought, but ultimately speak truth to power, the challenge is flipped back to the viewer. How should we view heroes? When we know that they â€œget their hands dirtyâ€ with politics; they forge convenient alliances; they stage publicity stunts; they do everything not for the greater good, but to push their own ambitions. How should we question our leaders and speak truth to power when we can also benefit from them if only we played our cards right?Looking at the trilogy as a whole, it is clear that our heroes, despite their contributions to the nation, are flawed individuals. Despite their larger-than-life personas, they are just people too. Like us. The whole time we were focused on the titular characters, on supposed saviors we have preconceived perceptions on. But this conclusion just reminded us we ought to look at ourselves and our relationship with these heroes too.

I didn't know what to expect when I first walked into the cinema, but I'm glad I went to see this film. It took me a beat to remember who Joven Fernando was because it's been so long since I saw the two earlier films, but once I remembered it made me appreciate the decision to insert an audience avatar into this remix of Philippine history. It's not a perfect film and it leans too heavily on exposition several times (e.g. one character notably sketches Quezon's pre-presidential career in the space of a minute, as if he were reading from a Wikipedia entry), but as a whole I enjoyed the creative decisions made and the liberties taken. The best thing about it, by far, is the performances by its cast. Jericho Rosales, Cris Villanueva, Romnick Sarmenta, and Mon Confiado in particular were wonderful to watch. (I also enjoyed Iain Glen as Leonard Wood, though at times the accent wasn't quite there.) I can already hear the arguments that are going to bubble up because of how politicians and the people are rendered in this film--but then aren't those arguments the point?

As someone who really enjoyed Araling Panlipunan in elementary and junior high school, and a huge Bayaniverse fanâ€”watching this film was an absolute treat for me. (Not to mention the outstanding visuals, humor, and score in this film, absolute chef kiss!)I love how it went beyond the usual, surface-level lessons we get in school. I remember learning about the Tydingsâ€“McDuffie Act back in sixth grade and wishing we could explore it more deeply but was ultimately met with disappointment when we only touched on it briefly before moving on to another topic. That being said, hearing familiar names and events in this movie made me geek out so much. More than that, I truly appreciated how it gave a deeper look into Quezonâ€™s life and not just his role in our history. I liked that the film showed his flaws and his â€œdark games,â€ making him feel more real and human.Without giving away any more spoilers, this film is both thought-provoking and relevant today. It leaves us with something important to reflect on: to question, to stay aware, and to take an active role in shaping our nation. The future is in our handsâ€”we must act before it changes us.Lahat ng bagay ay lilipas din; darating ang panahon na ang mga pangulo at mga nasa kapangyarihan ay bababa rin. Nawaâ€™y magsilbing paalala ang pelikulang ito na matutong mag-isip, maging mapagmatyag, at tumindig para sa tama. Huwag tayong maging uto-uto. Oo, the world isnâ€™t simply black and white but I do hope that we try our best to choose whatâ€™s right. Overall, this is a good end to the bayaniverse trilogy. Concluding the Bayaniverse trilogy, Quezon is a battle of wit and strategy, a game of outsmarting and outplaying in a race for political power that ultimately shaped the past, present, and future of the Philippines.I love how it incorporates a filmmakerâ€™s perspective through Nadia, as well as the return of Joven, now older, and the reemergence of journalism at the forefront. This use of cinema itself as a device to propel the narrative forward makes it compelling, seamlessly blurring the lines between fact and fiction, much like how the main characters easily manipulate these concepts.Despite clearly steering away from the literal warfare of the previous two installments, the film still manages to grip audiences through a high-stakes chess match between the titular character and his rivals.

Had a great time with this and it's a refreshing injection of optimism for the Philippine cinema scene. Love that our theater was packed and our audience was constantly engaged with every bit of dialogue, every Rosales enunciation, and every plot turn - the theater experience definitely amplified it. I cannot emphasize how lovely it is how this film ignited film discourse that I haven't felt about a local movie in a while since Heneral Luna.Jerrold Tarog's direction and screenplay with Rody Vera feel so ambitious in its approach to this type of film. The confidence seeps through every scene and how we're carried through scene by scene through its Hollywood level production design, editing, costume design, and unique biographical structure. Always been wowed at the idea of Joven Hernando and who he represents and this is all the more captivating as what transpires in this film. I felt like it may have some minor pacing issues that don't really tank the movie but it might've helped to have certain scenes/sequences a bit tighter.Jericho Rosales makes up for not looking like Casey through his fantastic line deliveries and not breaking a sweat while embodying this fascinating gray area of a man. Confiado (loved his presence very extra this time), Eusebio, and Villanueva also give fantastic turns as mostly returning cast members while Kris Villanueve takes over Joven easily. I missed you in this one, Epy as Mabini.As the emphatic period to TBA Studios' highly impressive Bayaniverse trilogy, it felt appropriate enough to lean more into the Oppenheimer-esque epic tale as opposed to just giving us another Luna story. This is not an action-packed war flick but rather a captivating portrait of political power plays, American colonial dynamics, and the roots of so many of our problems today. I'm sure there's more to take away from it and I'm going to continue browsing the internet to find out what else - that's what makes this movie-loving thing so much fun.

Aesthetics and design-wise, they definitely nailed it.Story, plot, and historical authenticity-wise, they flunked it. I think a majority of viewers, myself included, would expect a creative educational interpretation of Quezon's life, as opposed to a travesty of him through making half of the movie a glorified gossip show; conjectures right and left. This movie missed out so much, Quezon's childhood, career during the Philippine Revolution and the Philippine-American War, and his helping hand towards the fleeing Jews during the Holocaust. The story feels so inadequate and incomplete, so much missing puzzles.

ano ba kasing lasa ng independencia?anw, nalungkot ako sa pelikulang 'to, hindi dahil dismayado ako sa execution (na napakahusay, btw), pero dahil sa katotohanan na ang setting nito ay noon pang okupasyon ng mga dayuhan pero hanggang ngayon, napapanahon pa rin. isa pang punto ay may mga pulitikong nagsisimulang may tunay na layuning maglingkod sa masa pero katagalan, nagiging uhaw na lang sila sa kapangyarihan at naghahari-harian. sabi ni machiavelli, one can descend power by wicked and nefarious means and through the wishes of his fellow citizens--to which ig quezon was granted with both. and yes, the power was there, but the what happened to the love for the country?may quote na tumatak sa 'kin, "masyadong maraming pulitiko sa bansa, kakaunti lang ang lingkod-bayan". hays. kailan ba tayo kolektibong magigising? teka, kung magising man, may aaksyon kaya? ang hirap nga namang mulat ka pero walang kilos. parang mga sleep paralysis demons lang 'tong mga nasa pwesto kung gano'n haha. pero ayun, bandang huli, tanginang niyo pa ring lahat mga trapo.

WOW. WOW. WOW. WOW.Can't believe that's the conclusion of the Bayaniverse trilogy, a mere transition from the violent Revolution to the ego-driven politics.From the epic and fierceness of Heneral Luna, from the heartbreak and beautiful sights of Goyo, now to the perception of heroism through Quezon.Echo really killed this role, alongside Sarmenta, Villanueva, Confiado, and Sir Iain Glen.He really is one helluva egoist ngl. Love the callbacks to the previous films, the flashback scenes of our previous leads, the callback to the "Ang tao may damndamin ay hindi alipin." scene and the fierce energy and the tons of PI and PYTA based from Heneral Luna, the quotes from Pule (Mabini) and the beautiful color grading from Goyo, and notable characters from the respective films!I feel like theres gonna be fanfics about 70 (Quezon x OsmeÃ±a). They had such chemistry in this film more than their spouses.Throughout the Bayaniverse, this just shows that in history, there are no heroes and villains, just humans with flaws. From each film, we learn about each characters' traits and flaws that are something we can learn from them. Like our fav character throughout the trilogy, Joven Hernando, we are the observants, observing the two sides of a coin of each sides. Our voice may be silent as we watch, but the truth and the voice we yearn for is loud.What a nice conclusion to the trilogy, thank you TBA and Direk Jerrold Tarog for giving us great movies that we can go back and learn all about our country's history. Onto the new era...the Panguloverse."Our democracy will die...kung wala si Magsaysay..."

Quezon Thoughts:Production wise, medyo similar vibes siya sa Heneral Luna. Pero instead of war, dirty politics ang topic. Ganda nung part na pinakita nila difference ni Aguinaldo at Quezon, kung paano sila mag campaign ngayon. Mapapansin din similarities ng campaigns today kay Quezon. Joven:May anak na si Joven!!!! May fave character since HL. Kaso dito for some reason parang di na siya yung eyes nating viewers, parang part na talaga siya ng current cast. Di ko makuha yung Joven vibes kahit nandito yung actor na gumanap sa last 2 movies. Isa pa, parang under utilized siya sa ending. Yung anak niyang si Nadia parang cutout from that era talaga. May vibes siyang ganon ang ganda ng pagkakacast. Di ko magets yung cameo ni Cong at Iza. Ang random. Yung kay Iza parang iisipin mo na may malaki siyang character sa past movies dahil sa reaction niya pero wala naman??? Si Cong akala mo di solid north eh. Medyo nakakaawa si Aguinaldo dito. Lalo na nung pinaalis siya sa farm at tinanggalan ng pension. Dumi ni Quezon. Pero katulad niya mga pulitiko ngayon. Medyo nakakamiss Mabini-Aguinaldo tandem sa movie na 'to. Sayang deads na si Mabini, nakakamiss presence niya. Galing ni Jericho Rosales. Biggest what if si TJ Trinidad eh pero galing din naman ni Echo. Grabe yung pagkadramatic niya, yung accent, yung vibes niya with Sergio(old man yaoi sabi sa twitter). Galing ni Echo i portray yung kahambugan at kabwisitan ni Quezon. PS I hate it nung sinabi ko sa tatay ko na nanood ako ng Quezon at ang reaction niya is "ay gawa gawa lang yan eh".

Akala ko noon, tanga ang mga Pilipino, gaya ko. Ngunit habang tumatagal ang buhay ko sa mundong ito, unti-unti kong napagtatanto na napakatalino pala ng mga Pilipino â€” sa maling paraan nga lang.Gaya nga sa pelikulang ito, ang mga matatalinong may kapangyarihan ang patuloy na nagpapabilog sa atin at sa ating bayanâ€¦ na para nga ba tayong kulangot.Isang malaking kahihiyan sa hanay ng matatalinong tao, ng mga Pilipino, ang mga itinuturing bayani ng ating bansa. Simula noon hanggang ngayon, ang mga namumuno sa ating bansa ay itinuturing pa rin tayong mga â€œlaruan.â€ Kapwa Pilipino nga talaga ang papatay sa ating bayan. Kailan kaya natin makakamit ang totoong independencia?Gusto ko lang ding sabihin na: MABUHAY ANG PELIKULANG PILIPINO!Salamat sa ating mga malikhain na kababayan; nang dahil sa inyo, patuloy pang mabubuksan ang isipan ng ating mga kababayan.Mahal ko ang Pilipinas, pero ang mga Pilipinong alagad ng sining ang nagpatibay ng aking pagmamahal sa ating inang bayan.

I canâ€™t deny that the reactions and condemnations expressed by some of Quezonâ€™s descendants are valid. No matter which angle you look at it, the film portrayed a negative and unflattering image of Quezon during his lifetime.From his beginnings as a lawyer, to his time as governor of Tayabas, Senate President, and eventually as President â€” the movie showed how deeply rooted traditional politics was, even back then. Maybe they were the ones who started it; the methods may have changed over time, but the goal remained the same â€” to gain and keep power.Itâ€™s hard to accept that our own ancestors might have been the ones who taught us how to become monsters in the world of politics â€” corrupt and power-hungry. But hopefully, this film serves as an eye-opener for all of us â€” a reminder not to repeat the same history. May it inspire the next generation of public servants to have a genuine love for the country and to serve with true integrity and sincerity.

â€œI got one more in me,â€ exclaimed Jerrold Tarrog as he laid the finishing touches of his 3rd film in this ironically-titled Bayaniverse.Wilfredo Garrido has this scathing accusation that Quezon in its entirety is a hackjob in itself. It's very easy to glean the bias from which his status update after watching the film errs on, and I feel the need to start from this note because by no means does the film really sit on the fence.In fact, and if I may declaratively highlight in all its fictional and non-fictional aspects, Quezon sits as one of Jerrold Tarog's best pieces for being able to angle this part of history in a way never really seen. The recurring clamor for a film that talks of the Philippine Commonwealth has been something desired of, and Quezon being able to position itself in this manner is a welcome one.At the end of the day, one is left sitting at Quezon and possibly thinking about how the Philippine government is fundamentally a government of demons of all shapes and sizes. If you come out of this film arguing that the film itself makes Aguinaldo look like a saint (someone on Twitter says this), you may want to rewatch Heneral Luna as the center of all this is a series of heroes who are profoundly individual at their core, espousing social values and claiming to be champions of the greater good.Addendun: Raymond Red during a talkback of his Bayani (1992) screening earlier recalls the uproar he faced from the academic community for being the first to depict Aguinaldo as a piece of shit. In a way, history corrects itself down the line and one could only glean that reception towards Quezon will face the same developments.

I had the chance to experience watching this film in the Cinemas. Jericho Rosales as Quezon didn't disappoint, as well as the other actors. I love cinematic scene shown at first, the silent film theme one made by Nadia where he was portrayed as a good guy for his campaign, even though the contents of it are far from truth and how we're watching from Joven's perspective because the contents of the film revisiting Quezon before entering politics and during it is all in a film made by Nadia, a second version with more truth contrasting what she had made for his Ninong for Presidential Campaign. My thoughts on this film is that they executed the film really well. It showed their flaws, not just their good side. I like Joven Hernando's character, he's a fictional character but represent us really well. All of his lines really aligns with what the audience thinks when watching the film. From supporting and believing Quezon to questioning him and eventually criticizing him. It also reminded me of how Schools always teach and portrayed them as great heroes, but never really show what's behind the door. OsmeÃ±a's character is someone easily swayed with sweet words and Quezon took advantage of that, leading, swaying him with his words even though they've had their own disputesâ€”rivalry turned allies. Roxas's character is like a child, easy to be pawn. Quezon's character was portrayed as someone good at playing a game at politics, he knows how to play his cards very well; using every tactic and opportunities just like how he used Patriotism and Independence as a Propaganda. They also showed Quezon's side being a Womanizer and portrayed him as someone always concerned with good image in the publicâ€”although his bad side was shown, it still wouldn't erase the great things he did but it's refreshing to see that this film didn't glorify anyone. It instead showed that even these people in the end of the day are Humans. They're not perfect or saints, they have their own flaws. You can also see how our government back then still mirrors our present government. Corruption isn't new, it has always been there. There's a lot of things that you can realize watching this film, I wouldn't really rely on it for accuracy, after all it's mixed with fiction, myths and certain rumours for humour, that's why it's still better to research thoroughly. Overall this is a great film, Jerold Tarog and Tba Studios never disappoint! We need more films like this, tackling our own History.Truth is a great ideal, but you can't always use it to rule.I'm the Philippines I will lead this nation to Prosperity

Body and soul?Jerold Tarog's "Quezon" narrates a period of our history that mirrors the current state of politics in the country. Men in power takes advantage of the other men in the circle and, when its not convenient anymore, easily, casually dropping them dead. History, almost 100 years ago, is repeating itself. The dirty tricks, power-hunger, and betrayal that happened under the Commonwealth government employed by President Quezon are not new to me. My history lessons, albeit shallow, have taught me that while we recognize the efforts of our forefathers, they were after all human and susceptible to corruption. It is politics afterall. What surprised me tho is how this part of the country's history was presented through this film. The cinematography, sound production, and set designs, and of course the acting (especially Jericho Rosales) were beautifully blended considering the theme of politics and history. Should you watch it on a big screen? YES-- its a no-brainer.
When Filipinos learn to accept that our politicians are not perfect, flawed, and should not be held in a higher regard than an ordinary person, then maybe we will see a true change in our society.

After watching Quezon, I wondered: what was the directorâ€™s goal in this movie?While discussions suggest that the intention was to reveal the flawed person behind someone most people consider a hero, I canâ€™t help but askâ€”then what? What did it aim to achieve after that?For me, it merely opened up a controversy without offering any resolution. Itâ€™s similar to hearing endless news about corruption in the country without actually seeing justice served. Has anyone even been jailed yet?After tarnishing Quezonâ€™s name and linking him to the culture of political patronage and under-the-table negotiations, what was the movie really calling for? This is one of the things I find lacking in the film.I was also confused about Jerichoâ€™s acting choices and the directorâ€™s decisions regarding narration. I understand that comedy can be an effective way to deliver a message in a relatable manner, but to me, the messageâ€”still unclearâ€”was blurred by the slapstick. Tarog's disclaimer at the beginning and his response to Quezon's grandchild also did not help in his attempt to convey his message.And really, is that an attempt to give redemption to Aguinaldo?

Wrapping up a trilogy about the Philippines' revolutionary past with a relatively uneventful political biopic about some unremarkably corrupt politician really is a bold and interesting choice. Moreover, Quezon really is a rejection of the two films that came before.By no fault of its own, Heneral Luna is one of the most misunderstood and bastardized cautionary tales about patriotism and masculinity I've seen in my lifetime. Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral is a bitter demolition of the mindless jingoism and fascism that Heneral Luna became synonymous with. Finally, Quezon is a eulogy to the Philippines' revolutionary hopes and idealism; a resignation to a pathetic country's inescapable doom under so-called Great Men and self-proclaimed patriots.Problem is, Quezon is also the weakest of the trilogy from a structural level. Its transition from a winking mockery of the cosmic joke that is Filipino government to the bleak demystification of Quezon's self-made myth isn't as smooth as it could've been. The film's dragging length is impossible to deny by the midway point, though it's understandable given how long Quezon's story is. Worst of all, a literal half of Quezon's dialogue is a preachy lecture told at the audience. More than once, characters stop everything to become mouthpieces for the ideologies they represent and the timely commentary they embody. None of this is diegetic, and it's as awkward as it sounds. I also don't really jive with how the film ends by blaming the Filipinos for things and bastards they can't control. I too am disillusioned, but come on now with this ivory tower shit.Then again, after seeing how Heneral Luna's point was deliberately ignored, used to prop up a murderous shithead, then basically losing a decade in the process, I'm not too surprised by Quezon treating Filipino viewers like a bunch of gullible idiots who need everything to be spoon-fed at least twice.

2025 RankedTBA Studios RankedBACKGROUNDThis franchise is one of the most unique franchises out there by connecting Philippine historical films with each other into a singular cinematic universe, which is distinct from those that are fictional in nature. There are fictional elements in these films, but they are overall based on true events. It may not be as popular as other franchises that have existed for decades, but it does not have to be, considering that the number of movies are three so far. Regardless, it is still a franchise that I am going to look forward to for its next entry.POSITIVESThe gap between Quezon from the previous film, Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, is seven years, which could be a bit too long to wait, but it was worth it because I did not expect for the third installment to turn out to be the best in the franchise so far. The tone and style of filmmaking was different compared to its predecessors, which reflects how much Jerrold Tarog has grown as a filmmaker. The choice to use the early stages of film as a way to reflect and criticize him as a leader not only adds more creativity and style to the film but also reflects the phase of technology at the time, and how it can be used as a powerful tool to spread influence. The storytelling is not straightforward or linear, but it is organized into chapters based on who Manuel Quezon has to face or deal with in order to rise in power. It is an approach that I did not expect, but it is a success for being able to tell a cohesive story. Jericho Rosales's portrayal is one of the aspects that I was looking forward to seeing in the film, and he succeeded my expectations. He has so much command, control, and confidence in his performance. His enthusiasm and charisma match his goal to elevate his status by playing "mind games" with his opponents. This puts the audience in an unsettling position because it becomes clear the kind of leader Manuel Quezon was. There are moments that would make me feel the intensity and pressure as I am piecing out the next moves of each player and the events that could happen. The production design was impressive that made me wonder about how they were built or where they were located. I also admire the various use of cinematography like panning and tracking to make the film livelier and to set the tone.MIXEDI was really impressed by the editing of this film, but there is a particular scene where the editing did not work for me because I felt that it did not fit into its tone. This film has the most number of significant characters in the franchise and there are a lot of time jumps, which makes it a bit difficult to catch up with certain plotlines for me, but it is understandable because it reflects how complex and complicated the situations are.NEGATIVESDue to how plenty the characters are, some of them were not given enough depth. There are a few of lines of humor that did not work for me.CONCLUSIONIt is clear how the film wants Manuel Quezon to be portrayed, which they were able to accomplish. The tone and genre of this film may not be similar to the past films in the franchise like scenes involving gunshots, but its unique approach to the story makes it stand out from other Philippine historical films.

Gets ko si Joven. When you sit down and watch the film as it starts, highly likely you will suddenly be reminded of how Heneral Luna and Goyo wentâ€”the first two movies of Bayaniverseâ€”and your expectation would somehow be related to those two. But Tarog did a different approach in Quezon, where satire is ultimately obvious, as much as it is also intended to be taken seriously. The fast-pace approach, the quick-changing of scenes, the conversations which aren't dragging, and riddles exchanged between the characters. These same characters delivered well and Tarog made sure the comedic stance are appropriately placed where necessary. It's just that for the majority of the time, I have this moment where the scenes are already at its peak, only to be steered in a different direction since, clearly, this film wants to tell more. I guess 2 hours will never be enough. I've always admired how he interpreted Luna and Goyo in a way that is culturally and politically provoking, yet easy to grasp, relate to, and branches out even more questions. Looking back at the Quezon film, itâ€™s hard not to realize how little weâ€™ve actually progressed as a country. We never truly learned. We forget too easily, and us being gullible, though partly not our fault, continues to hold us back. That's why it's vital that a fictional character like Joven Hernando comes in as a storyteller. We need a narrator that subtly contributes to the narrative, yet obviously part of it. He witnessed three generations of it all, with his perspective changing and honing, and revolving with the three personalities - Luna, Goyo, and now, Quezon. We are Joven. And would you ever disagree with Joven knowing that to our core, he is the representation of us all?Joven proved that as a nation, we want change. But individually? We really just wanted to survive, to focus on our families, to build our career around the things we love doing the most. At the same time, we want to see our country thrive, see it receive its deserved peace and rightful independence. We believe it's ours to begin with and no one should take that away from us. That's how us, Filipinos. We struggle to keep moving as a progressive nation because our minds are cut in halfâ€”in many pieces for someâ€”because we have a lot to think about. Sa dulo ng bawat araw, karamihan sa atin gusto lang umuwi, magpahinga, at siguraduhing kinabukasan ay may pagkaing nakahain sa lamesa. Kaya gets ko si Joven. Kung nalinlang man siya, kung napaniwala man siya nila Luna, Goyo, at Quezon, at kung kumapit man siya sa kakarampot na pag-asa mula dun sa tatlo, hindi niya naman talaga kasalanan. Gaya ng karamihan, nagtiwala lang din siya. Kasi sino bang aayaw sa pangakong kalayaan para sa isang bansang inaabuso at kumakalam ang sikmura?As film goers, audience, and product of PH education, our role is to scrutinize and be doubtful, along with enjoying the film, because at the end of the day, a film remains a form of art, and art supposedly have its interpretation by whoever is looking at it. Truthfully, this is where the film draws the lineâ€”it cannot show everything. It's up to the audience to make their own research and form their opinions.

Nagkaroon kami ng isang diskurso pauwi pagkatapos naming panoorin ang Quezon. Matapos ko pa lang masaksihan ang pelikulang ito ay batid ko na ang ipinapahiwatig nito, hindi kailanman magiging malinis ang pulitika sapagkat ito ay laro lamang sa mata ng mga namumuno. Ang manipulasyon ni MLQ ay tila masasabi kong napakagaling, hindi kapuri-puri ngunit nakakamanghang bawat hadlang na kanyang haharapin ay mayroong plano kahit na hindi pa ito magtagumpay.Isa lamang ang konklusyon na makukuha rito, mula noon hanggang ngayon, mula kay Aguinaldo, Quezon, Duterte, at Marcos ay walang pinagbago ang namumuno sa ating bansa. Kaya naman, bumoto ng tama at bumoses para sa mamamayang Pilipino!P.S. We saw Mr. Mon Confiado and Benjamin Alves in the flesh and they even gave a small talk! Thank you direk for this film :)
